THE COLLAB YOU DIDN'T KNOW YOU NEEDEDAs I've experienced a sunday in Hong Kong with my aunts, I can say that they accurately depicted a DH's life. Side characters helped a lot in building the love team's chemistry. They brought life that if they weren't in the movie, it will be boring. Kakai, Maymay, Joross, Jeff, and specially to Lovely. (Pero ang oa lang konti ng ilonggo accent) Alden is unleashed and at his best. Just give Kathryn an Oscar already! Just with her eyes, she can win an acting award. Screenplay is strong and cinematography is great. There's no wonder if this would be a blockbuster hit-- a crowd pleaser. Perfect amount of cheesiness, dilemma and PAIN. I recommend it.MA!-gandaMA!-nood na kayo hahahaP.S. Bakit daw ampopogi ng kapatid ni Alden

Ganda! Ang galing ng pagkakagamit ng timely issue of immigration to weave a beautiful, funny and relatable story. Ang painful nung subplot ng mom ni Joy. Would love to have it explored more, prequel, perhaps?

Watched Hello, Love, Goodbye at SM North EDSA Cinema 6.Its first hour & last 15 minutes tells an interesting, heartening, compelling and high-spirited OFW story fueled with great acting from Kathryn Bernardo. But Director Cathy Garcia Molina defecates those usual Star Cinema formulaic SHIT that stinks the middle part of the storyTOO BAD!The first hour of Hello Love Goodbye sets up an interesting & heartening plot & main character.Kathryn Bernardo portrays an empowering existential libertarian take of a Pinay OFW torn between her JOY dreams & obligation.But Director Cathy Garcia Molina poops many formulaic Star Cinema SHIT ruining the film.Hello Love Goodbye reminds me of Kita KitaHello Love Goodbye could've followed the cinematic style and storytelling structure of Kita Kita to be a great film.Kathryn Bernardo‚ù§Ô∏èAlden Richards is comparable with Alessandra De Rossi ‚ù§Ô∏è Empoy Marquez#Kathden ~= #AlempoyIf only Direk Sigrid Bernardo be the director instead of Cathy Garcia-MolinaHello Love Goodbye could've been a great, well-made and well-treated film.Hello Love Goodbye works only at its first hour and its last 15 minutes of the film.The film lays out an interesting and compelling plot as well as a Kathryn Bernardo main character as Joy that we would all sympathize and root for.The concept of spiritually living in transit in a strange foreign land working hard to make a desired reality happen one day is the film's conceit that really hits hard to all of us. In this modern, demanding and even depriving world we are living in, we are all racing against time to reach our desired goals in life or else we would never achieve it.No time for JOY, no time for LOVE, no time to enjoy our current disposition NOW.This is pretty SMART stuff for a Filipino OFW story.We always watch Filipino films about OFWs where the OFW main character always sacrifices his/her life and personal well-being to fulfill his/her responsibilities to the family he/she left behind in the Philippines.This is a long worn-out story and we had enough of it.Hello Love Goodbye turns the table around.Instead of highlighting the selfless sacrifice of a typical Filipino OFW, the film smartly tackles an examination of a lonely OFW's existence in a foreign land balancing what he/she really likes against what he/she is supposed to do.I believe Hello Love Goodbye opens this paradigm which really hooks my attention and root for the story.Kita Kita almost touches this ingenious examination of OFW but never gets there as Direk Sigrid Bernardo never intends to portray such theme. Direk Cathy Garcia-Molina since "My Perfect You", "The Hows of Us" and "Three Words To Forever" is exploring and digging further her creative mind in coming up with ingeniously joyous Filipino stories while keeping that worn-out and obsolete Star Cinema Filipino family rom-com formula.Hello, Love, Goodbye is Kathryn Bernardo at her BEST so far. Good thing she escapes and breaks off from the tight-bound clutches of her constant leading man, Daniel Padilla. Therefore, Kathryn Bernardo is truly FREE as an actress and as a woman. Without Daniel Padilla at her side, Kathryn Bernardo did not fall down but instead rose higher than what she used to be just as an eye-candy amateur teeny bop damsel of a brute teenage heartthrob debonair.Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in Hello Love Goodbye successfully and convincingly emulates the existential crisis a Filipino OFW has to face as she braves working in transit in a strange foreign land while examining her choices and personal well-being in life. There is a strong libertarian take on Hello Love Goodbye that makes me like the film at first. And Kathryn Bernardo's great acting make that happen loud and bright on the big SM Cinema big screen. Again, this is smart stuff and Kathryn Bernardo as Joy would be one of the most striking Filipino movie characters that I have watched. At least on the film's strong first hour.Alden Richards plays Ethan who is more of a sassy comic relief yet effective MPDG for Kathryn Bernardo as Joy. His character as Ethan started out as a male creep stalking Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in a misogynist distasteful manner that even Senator Risa Hontiveros would never approve of. I guess Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is trying to make a Daniel Padilla out of Alden Richards with Daniel Padilla always bullying or tormenting Kathryn Bernardo for her to love him. Ahem! Direk Cathy. May Safe Spaces Law na tayo thanks to Senator Risa Hontiveros. Any naive sexualized young male Filipino doing a Daniel Padilla or Alden Richards to a Kathryn Bernardo is a crime punishable by fines or at worst, jail time.But I really DO NOT MIND Alden Richards portraying as a sex-crazy playboy luring Kathryn Bernardo into a one-night stand. I believe his flawed character gives merit to the powerful first hour and what Hello Love Goodbye is supposed to be.But I do wonder if Direk Cathy Garcia Molina inject that sex maniac character flaw for the male MPDG to justify that one-night stand motel scene. Seems Direk Cathy and the Filipino masses are really after Kathryn Bernardo shoving her face to Alden Richard's bare muscular chest. OMG! No wonder Daniel Padilla never passionately supports Hello Love Goodbye! üòÇ I actually like the unusual pairing of the troubled & serious Kathryn Bernardo with the carefree & hypersexual Alden Richards.This unusual pairing reminds me of Alexandra de Rossi and Empoy Marquez of Kita Kita.The Kathden dynamic in Hello Love Goodbye could have been a more improved, more substantial version of Alempoy in Kita Kita.Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards interacting in Hello Love Goodbye is similar to those sassy Asian (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) teenage romcoms that I get to watch on HBO Red Channel. Only, the Kathden may be something more meaningful than a unusual campy romantic/sexual pairing.Yup! The first half of Hello Love Goodbye really sets us up for a promising story that I am eager to watch.Until the second half came which quickly abandons this great promising story for Direk Cathy Garcia Molina to POOP to us the standard Star Cinema formulaic SHIT that STINKS already!Hello Love Goodbye starts well.The film establishes an interesting, heartfelt OFW story, introduces a charismatic, relatable and empowering female Kathryn Bernardo lead character and builds up an uncanny yet endearing relationship between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards.Am really expecting the real plot to unravel on the second half.However, I got appalled when Hello Love Goodbye suddenly shifts into your typical standard shitty Star Cinema family romcom formula that is so uncalled for!This really RUINED the movie!Depriving and ROBBING us of a great story to unravel.NABITIN na, NAGOYO pa tayo sa Hello Love Goodbye na ito!From an inspiring, heartfelt and empowering OFW story on the first hour;Hello, Love, Goodbye suddenly drops everything and shifts into a cheesy standard bloated Star Cinema romcom love story with lots of these shit:1. Unnecessary kilig moments, 2. Blatant over exposure of unnecessary supporting charactrers3. Instant falling-in-love that does not feel earned and 4. Speedy resolutions that does not make a big impact to the hearts and minds of the audience.So Cathy Garcia Molina still adopts her standard Star Cinema family romcom formula into the promising Hello Love Goodbye story even when the film does not really need it!Resulting to a big pile of mainstream Star Cinema SHIT taking over the 2nd half of the film.The Star Cinema formulaic SHIT forced upon on the 2nd part of Hello, Love, Goodbye feels like a typical shitty Star Cinema story of its own. Therefore, Hello, Love, Goodbye NEVER continues, NEVER finishes and CUTS SHORT its REAL and promising OFW story that it masterfully sets up at the start.We are DEPRIVED of watching a great story until the end in Hello, Love, Goodbye. The typical Star Cinema family romcom formula that Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is fond to insert is not bad always.This overused family formula does work well for some of the following Cathy Molina's films:1. "You Changed My Life" starring Sarah Geronimo and John Lloyd Cruz2. "My Perfect You" starring Gerald Anderson and Pia Wurtzbach and 3. "The Hows of Us" starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla......But NOT "Hello Love Goodbye"!Instead, this Star Cinema formula injected at the middle part of Hello, Love, Goodbye causes a sudden change of the story, making me feel that I am not watching the continuation of its promising first half.This Star Cinema romcom formula which thrills the Filipino masses, unfortunately causes a big void at the 2nd half of the real promising story of Hello Love Goodbye.Which is TOO BAD and VERY DISAPPOINTING!It is really STUPID for Star Cinema ever since to forcibly insert that singular usual repetitive worn-out family romcom formula on most Star Cinema movies of varying stories.FUCK! SO STUPID INDEED!While this worn-out formula works on some films, it FAILS miserably and RUINS so many Star Cinema films.Including "Hello, Love, Goodbye" as its latest casualty!The audience never gets to watch the REAL, more heartfelt OFW story of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and her libertarian existential adventures with Alden Richards as Ethan.Instead, we get to watch another typical Star Cinema formulaic romantic SHIT which should not be part of the real story.Just like any other typical Star Cinema filmsHello Love Goodbye is so BLOATED.1. Maymay Entrata is so underutilized! Although she has a charming potential to have an Pinay HK OFW movie of her own.2. Alden Richards as Ethan's personal existential struggle may not be necessary but should not be emphasized as much as the struggles of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy.3. Alden Richards as Ethan's family should never be one of the main focus of the film.4. Alden and Kathryn's friends should never overstay their welcome to the real story.5. Maxine Medina is a beautiful yet useless distraction to the movie!6. Those kilig scenes are so forced upon Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo. The REAL story does not even require for Ethan and Joy to madly fall in love and become sassy sweethearts.7. Finally, the interesting sub-story of Maricel Laxa as Joy's mother who is forced to marry a foreigner to secure a resident's visa is so not explored further. Too bad!These bloated 2nd half of Hello Love Goodbye gives us unnecessary SHIT while DEPRIVING us of the real stakes of the story that really matter.I assume that Cathy Garcia Molina intend to portray the over-glamorized 2nd hour to be Ethan and Joy's existence in the NOW.With this, the film really falters.But Hello, Love, Goodbye redeemed itself on the last 15 minutes of the film.It is actually the real resolution to the existential OFW crisis that both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are facing.But it is TOO LATE!A big void is left on the 2nd half of the film which fails to bear fruit the promising OFW story that the film first introduces to us.Hello, Love, Goodbye could have worked if its 2nd hour is a more serious, more composed, yet truly heartfelt & intelligently memorable adventures solely between Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and Alden Richards as Ethan.Both would continue to explore their libertarian existence together either as lovers or bffs. As they continue to work their asses off in Hong Kong, they continue to examine their existence, wants, needs, priorities and obligations.And that is where their prospect about love in the world of constant demands and uncertainties take place.All other supporting characters interact at their minimum as the real Hello Love Goodbye story is soley focused on Alden and Kathryn.This is how the movie should be if it were serious enough to be a great movie.I guess Hello Love Goodbye could've worked if it follows the story and cinematic style of Kita Kita.I do wish Cathy Garcia Molina consulted with Sigrid Bernardo on how to make Hello, Love, Goodbye work.Hello, Love, Goodbye is really a missed opportunity for Star Cinema.Rather than making a great movie which is a worthy follow-up to the great Quezon's Game movie 9/10.Star Cinema chose to inject the usual mainstream formulaic SHIT that really leaves a void on the potentially inspiring OFW story which really shortchanges the audience outright!P.S. As Hello, Love, Goodbye is an exhibition of Kathryn Bernardo at her bestAlden Richards at first plays a convincing & effective uncanny free-spirited character worthy of a companion for Kathryn Bernardo.Too bad Direk Cathy Garcia Molina fails to handle Alden Richards's good talent well in the film as she foolishly swings his character from a free-spirited sex-crazed playboy into a more serious yet passionate romantic.With this, Alden Richards still performs his best in his previous film, "Imagine You and Me" as Direk Mike Tuveria really puts Alden's talent to good use to make the ALDUB film work somehow."The Hows Of Us" may not be a great film. But its strength is its middle part which Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla exhibits that magical romantic feeling artfully around an old house that is really glamorously teasing our emotions.Some scenes before that mid-scene and the later scenes after are somewhat unnecessary and could be SHIT.But it didn't damage the story for its mid-scene is awesome."Hello, Love, Goodbye" is the opposite.The first half and the last 15 minutes of the film are GOLD in the story.However, the middle second half of the film suddenly turns to SHIT which irreversibly DAMAGED the integrity of the entire story and film.Finally, I also complain on how Hello, Love, Goodbye visually depicts the beautiful Hong Kong.The unusually bright lighting on various Hong Kong settings are slightly irritating to the eyes.I can't really determine if Hello, Love, Goodbye has poor cinematography or Direk Cathy Molina intends to have this visual flaw on purpose to support the real theme & message of the film.

You can look past through the sappy by it being filled with palpable OFW stories and heartfelt moments of almost every character (that scene when Joy sees her Nursing classmate having his honeymoon in HK, then is asked what is she doing there, what a tearjerker).It has many subplots about family, self-worth, career, and brief encounters that can stand alone, but their sum is a surprising and refreshing experience.(so much better when rewatchedü•≤)

It‚Äôs actually good! There were parts of the plot that would make a better, stand-alone film such as Joy and her mother, the tricks for survival for Filipino DHs in HK, among others. It was understandable that the movie fell for the blockbuster dilemma but in total, I can see how the writing process was thorough, impressive, and a tad frustrating.

It's the specificity that I enjoyed the most. There have been many movies about the OFW experience, but this one roots itself in the particulars of the Hong Kong domestic helper. They're women who have made the great sacrifice to be separated from their families for the sake of potential economic prosperity. But they labor under a system that seems intent on limiting them. They are given work, certainly, but they aren't free to seek other work. To do so is illegal. Joy is pursuing a dream, seeking a life beyond being the absent breadwinner for a family that doesn't feel her suffering. And because she wants more, she can't just stay within the very limited lines of her existence, risking arrest and deportation just to scrape together enough money to find a means to a better existence. In the margins, we see the internalized tragedy of a people convinced that this is somehow an acceptable situation: veteran domestic helpers constantly telling a neophyte that she'll get used to this life, a phone call back home that's about having to extend a contract another two years. And at the center, we learn about Joy's mother, whose tragic situation exemplifies the commodification of the Filipino woman, and the trauma that it brings.The relationship stuff is less specific. Ethan fits into the playboy made good archetype: a lothario who develops real feelings for a girl because she initially rejects him, and then seems to tirelessly pursue her despite her consistent pleas for him to stop. That's a lot less interesting, even though there are aspects to Ethan's story that are kind of intriguing as well. The film bends its story around the fate of their relationship, and it isn't quite able to make it feel weighty enough to stand up to the larger issues that the characters are facing. It's cute and stuff, but it feels like a distraction from the genuinely incisive examination of the Hong Kong OFW situation.But none of that erases all the good that the film does. Even as the romance takes the fore, the movie is smart enough to make it all feel burdened by the tragedies inherent to a people who have resigned themselves to the reality of a home that can no longer be their home. Also, Kathryn Bernardo is great in this. Joy is a fully formed character: an industrious young woman who has deferred her dreams under the pretense of a necessary selflessness, struggling under the weight of responsibility all while learning sad truths that will come to shatter her conception of the life she's been pursuing. There's a lot going on there, and Bernardo just takes it all in and makes it work. Good stuff.
My favorite part of the movie was when Maymay Entrata did an interpretative dance and ended her routine with a kamehameha

Pero aminin niyo, habang lalong tumatagal, mayroon siyang refreshing feeling. As a KathNiel fan since 2012 (Growing Up days, ganern), sobrang proud ako kay Kathryn‚Ä¶

One of the best Filipino romantic dramas I‚Äôve seen in a while. It has to be said that the movie is of its time; it has many layers that reveal much about the current social, cultural, economic, and political landscape. It moves you to redefine what it means to truly love someone. It‚Äôs definitely more than just a love story.

This is a film I normally don‚Äôt go for. I chickened out of a midnight screening of Midsommar and caught this one instead. (I felt I wasn‚Äôt mentally ready for that haha.)But I was surprised because this one wasn‚Äôt a walk in the park too‚Äîit dropped some heavy emotional bombs. With grace though. I liked it as a whole. Was it cheesy/sometimes overly romantic? Hell yeah. But it was good. Because it was honest. Honest is beautiful. Well-acted, too. I cried lots. And they portrayed the OFW life honorably and respectfully, I think. Never underestimate an OFW‚Äôs plight. As an immigrant‚Äôs kid, I deeply appreciated how this film didn‚Äôt shy away from the messy parts of life away from one‚Äôs home country‚Äîthe ugly parts of choosing to be displaced for some years in hopes of saving enough to build a better life for OTHERS who might not even deserve it. I liked the subtle commentaries. Life is unfair.It also didn‚Äôt present perfect characters, which is rare for a Filipino mainstream romance movie. This one had messy people. No hints of self-righteousness. And you can‚Äôt help but root for them because of that. I love films that do this. Remind you of the cheesiness and beauty of being human. Of falling in love, of owning pain, of being honest about hurting, of independence and codependency, of giving and dreaming.
ACTUALLY ENJOYED THIS. the side stories with their own families gave this good depth
3.75 Stars.

I fell in love with this film. It is a tear-jerker, heartfelt movie. Mga twice akong umiyak. Ewan ko ba bakit relate na relate ako kay Ethan. Baka pareho lang kami talaga ng personality, perspective about love. Yung willing ibigay ang lahat in the name of love. All or nothing sabi nga niya.Pero aside from that, yung hirap ng OFW talaga is yung central theme ng kwento. Yung pangarap mo versus pangarap mo para sa pamilya mo. Yung paano ka ba pipili sa ganun. Yung sitwasyon mo na wala ka naman choice.Salamat CGM for another worth na movie. Ang ganda niya in fairness.

Hello, Love, Goodbye starts with Joy (played by Kathryn Bernardo) saying something like, ¬®In Hongkong we don¬¥t waste time because every second counts and every second we are payed¬®. The film works best when it follows this premise- when Joy acts as the ¬¥kayod lang ng kayod¬¥ breadwinner of the family and when she desperately searches for ways to support her dream of flying to Canada to seek a job and follow her passion. However, when Ethan (played by Alden Richards) comes into the picture, this premise suddenly shatters, bringing back the movie to its commercial origin.A DIFFERENT CATHY GARCIA-MOLINA FILMThis film is envisioned to be like one of the remarkable classic OFW films in the past like ¬¥Dubai¬¥, and ¬¥Milan¬¥. Fortunately, the film doesn¬¥t settle for that vision alone. It raises the story, nuanced to experiences by domestic helpers based in Hong Kong, where it is illegal to take another job aside from being a DH. It also digs deeper, creating a more compelling and informative story about the overseas Filipino workers in Hong Kong. To this end, the film may be given credit for its thorough research.THE MIDDLE STUMBLESIt could have been great if the film lived up to that premise and made that nuanced Hong Kong experience as it`s core, but instead it uses the romantic narrative as a way to effectively communicate with its audience. It is here, in the halfway of the movie, where it fails to function as a compelling narrative piece. Just when Ethan comes into the picture, familiar Filipino movie production processes and cliches come into play. Take for example the Wattpad-ish treatment of Ethan¬¥s character, the way he is perceived as a playboy and later on revealed that he¬¥s not so bad after all because of previous traumas he had encountered, the cringey mix of English and Tagalog to try to create remarkable lines, inserting some product brands into the movie that never really contributes to the story, using some irrelevant sequences and drone shots that make the film look weird and the quality subpar, and most importantly the redundant score that¬¥s being played using different instruments to create a grandiose melodrama just like every Cathy Garcia-Molina film. Truth be told, there¬¥s really nothing that is compelling in the film¬¥s second part. It all looks like a really long pantomime with ¬®Kung ¬¥Di Rin Lang Ikaw¬® as background.THE SLIGHT RESURRECTIONThankfully, all the second part craze undos itself in the film¬¥s last few minutes. Here, the struggles of both Joy and Ethan are discussed and are powerfully put together to give the film a compelling touch, grounded to the themes presented in the film¬¥s opening. The last few minutes of the film however still feels like a long music video. Only this time, it¬¥s disguised as a travelogue. Although, it is in this long sequence where the most delightful shots are shown, it kind of feels just like a long compilation of tourist vlogs rather than an essential part of the story. Another resurrection comes at the film¬¥s last minute. It brilliantly presents the resolution, bringing it to a powerful last shot reminiscent to that of Alfonso Cuaron¬¥s `Roma¬¥, but more explicitly told.THE BEST OF KATHRYNI never thought I would say this, but this is definitely Kathryn¬¥s film. Though this is her most daring and demanding role yet, she perfectly portrays Joy¬¥s desperation, desire, and inherent sadness. This performance is her all-time best and I can, with no doubt say that it is something that should seriously be considered by the country¬¥s award-giving bodies. Alden Richard¬¥s Ethan however feels like a character that was written for Kathryn¬¥s on-screen partner, Daniel Padilla. Despite this, Alden Richards still plays the role with heart. Unlike Kathryn¬¥s role, Ethan is not a dramatically demanding character. This is somehow opposite to Richards¬¥ past roles which never fails to use tears and eye acting as tools for storytelling. In the end, it feels like Alden is only a supporting character in this movie. INCONSISTENTLY GOODSometimes, Hello, Love, Goodbye struggles to cope up with it¬¥s promising premise. At one point it proudly flaunts it¬¥s technical excellence, and the next thing you see, a drone is randomly used to show a scene where the main characters are running on a rooftop. Sometimes it also shines as a narrative piece while the next second, it reeks of shit. This film has a lot of potential, in all honesty. However, it does not consistently makes use of that potential, and most of the time it acts like one of those commercial films in the market- settles for the mediocre, and the audience appeal while sacrificing good storytelling. Despite this, it still should be regarded as a cinematic achievement as it presents a raw aspect of the difficult life abroad despite being a studio-made film.

Cathy Garcia-Molina has revitalized her storytelling voice. A good mix of crowd-pleasing moments and hard-to-swallow truths. The film didn‚Äôt pull any punches. It left me gushing and gut-wrenched at the same time.

Isang ehemplo ang "Hello, Love, Goodbye" na pedeng tibagin ang mga nakasanayan na nating tambalan, ipares sa iba pang tao, at pede pa ring makaramdam ng saya at kilig habang pinapanood sila. May kakaibang timpla ang tambalang Alden at Kathryn na hindi nakakasawang panuorin. üòÅ idagdag pa rito ang isang satisfying at hindi toxic na pagresolba sa issue nila sa pelikula.

Never have I ever watched a Filipino movie with the same typical couple until this came out, and this is one of the reasons why it was extraordinary. They had definitely given the audience another chemistry and vibe to maybe spice things up and break that notion of having the same couple on screen; however, what really made this movie so good is its plot. Every bit of its scene mirrors the reality of life and through that, true love is depicted in the story. You may bump into some cheesy and corny lines, but you could quite see how the two leads were able to emulate the vibes of Filipinos. If you're not into romantic type of movies, don't worry. You can still relate to it in some other perspective. Love can also be expressed in a platonic way. :) So, this is definitely a must watch.
As someone who‚Äôs so soft, idk how many times this movie made me cry!

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film I didn't expect to like. I went to the cinema with a passive indifference to pass the time, yet I was utterly blown away once the opening montage scene started. It reminded me of the claustrophobic isolation and weariness of Chungking Express, which also took place in Hong Kong. I thought to myself that it wasn't a bad start at all and it piqued my interest, hoping it manages to be consistently good throughout. And it did.The portrayal of domestic helpers is realistic. It doesn't go all the way to make it a tragic story, to the point of being depressing, as it manages to be hopeful at times with frequent lighthearted moments. I have a soft spot for stories about OFW struggles. Being a child of an OFW, I've witnessed various injustices prevalent in the OFW community. The movie brings to light several of them, and they hit home.Surprisingly, I didn't find the romance corny at all. Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards both come from different well-established love teams, and I was initially skeptical that a chemistry between them wouldn't work. However, they manage to exceed expectations as they bring the best out of each other. Kathryn portrayed the role of Joy convincingly as a struggling domestic helper trying to make ends meet and realize her dreams. Alden portrayed the role of Ethan as your typical playboy, but he manages to bring out enough nuance to an honestly flawed character escaping the ghosts of his past.The cinematography is decent, providing enough satisfactory camera angles to capture the scenic Hong Kong backdrop. The script is pretty standard for a Cathy Garcia-Molina film but sufficiently witty, sappy, and genuine all at once. The score is average but serviceable. Certain scenes could've had more emotional impact and tension without the dramatic music. The acting of some minor characters needs improvement. Despite that, it's not distracting when you have two lead characters pouring their heart out in their respective roles.To conclude, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn't just a typical straightforward romance film for me. It had enough going on in its story to be engaging while being paced well enough. The chemistry is there, and I must admit that the movie touched me in a way that other of its contemporaries haven't. Ultimately what resonated with me most in this particular film is how it addresses love in the most honest and vulnerable way possible. Every subplot is instrumental and significant to the film's conclusion, making a brutal yet optimistic statement that I rarely see in romance stories in general.
"Ang babae pag bigay nang bigay... tanga. Pag inuna naman ang sarili, masama. San ba talaga kami lulugar, Ate Vi? Di ko na alam eh. Ang pagmamahal ba sa sakripisyo lang maipapakita, ha?"
Pasok, Moira!

Very simple and straighforward. It put a spotlight on the hardships of Pinoy OFWs. It‚Äôs sometimes heartbreaking but you‚Äôll find beauty in those moments, too. Props to Alden for pulling this one off. I‚Äôm so happy to see him in these kinds of projects. Gone are the super pilit love team stories. I would want him to work with Mikhail Red next. And of course, Kathryn. This film is hers. She gave a monster of a performance.

Obviously not the director's best. natuwa ako kasi iba na yung naging ka-love team ni kath and tbh this performance is understandable na kasi first time niya nga na hindi si daniel yung katandem. Well anyway, i expected so much from this movie and from cathy garcia-molina --- siguro yun yung kaya feeling ko ang anticlimactic ng film na to. Di ko alam kung di ko lang talaga trip yung mga cliche na stuff pero, hindi ako nahook sa dialogue at may mga eksena na parang cringe fest lang. yung iba lang naman. may mga eksena pa din na napatawa ako, dahil kayla Kakai. My expectations for this were high because of the praise it has been getting, and it does not disappoint. Beyond the romance blossoming between the two leads, this shows the hardships and difficulties of life while living as an OFW (Oversees Filipino Worker) - the limited choices and the sacrifices the characters have to endure. Kathryn Bernardo gives a stellar performance as Joy - and this is possibly her best performance to date. She is clearly supported by her male co-star who reciprocates her performance though Bernardo is the center of the story. My primary issue with Filipino romance films is the direction the romance will take when the leads are faced with a dilemma. Usually it‚Äôs the woman who ends up self-sacrificing for love, or the issues of the man are not addressed while giving the couple their happy ending. Sometimes the ending could be a cop-out, instead of letting it naturally play out. This played out perfectly - it was sensible and realistic. There was no gimmick, and the direction their relationship headed addressed the situation the leads were in. This is one for the books.Also kudos to the cinematographer and the writer.

Kathryn's performance here was quintessential Kathryn, Kathryn on The Hows of Us was really the best I have seen from her. Akala ko I won't hold on to Alden's character. Parang nung una kasi it didn't match him; But to my surprise, his character grew. The way the film presented his character and how we got to know him better was very effective. (May I just note that Joross Gamboa's performance here was so hilarious? Like, as in sobrang benta ng jokes na kahit ano nalang din siguro lumabas sa bibig niya ay nakakatawa rito)Story wise, what I really did like was it didn't romanticize the hardships of our OFWs, it presented the harsh reality of working outside the country. Kathryn really captured it. The film wasn't really the dark, heavy drama-ish film but it made me reflect on the privileges that I have and shouldn't take for granted. Last note, sana mapalitan 'yung chroma part sa last scene choz

It is not a pabebe romcom film. It is not a puro hugot lines and heartbreaking songs film. This movie will prove that the tangent-line kind of relationship fate exists you might be meeting exactly once but you can still make great moments from it. So so so film.

A young Filipino woman working in Hong Kong meets a young bartender. She's about to complete her contract and go to greener pastures in Canada. Normally, I wouldn't go for this type of film. And it's by Cathy Garcia-Molina, so seeing her name normally makes me go to the opposite direction, having seen a few of her past films. But this one, to her credit, has a bit more substance. There's a compelling drama here about the plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW's) but blended with the formulaic romantic-dramedy that is her bread and butter. They do the usual "hugot" emotional romantic scene in the end where they telegraph every emotion through overly written emotional speeches each trying to out-romance each other. But it's still a solid drama before that.

a breath of fresh air. it's funny and sweet and heartbreaking without trying so hard. i especially love the fact that it doesn't revolve around ethan and joy, but mostly around ofws & their life outside. kath is amazing ((AS ALWAYS !1)) and you can really feel her every emotion in each scene. i love how she knows where she's going and how she's gonna get it. also i loved the tour around hk!! the shots where ethan and joy weren't the focus and they were just in the corner, giving the spotlight to hk's sights. thank u team *dog eyes*
i will always believe I'm the love child of ethan and joy

If there's one thing the movie can really boast about, it's the strength of the acting between its two leads. Kathryn Bernardo acted her heart out in this. You can literally feel the sweat, desperation and exhaustion her character endures in her stint as a domestic helper in Hong Kong. At this point, she proved that she can carry a movie all by herself. Alden Richards also proved here that he came a long way from his pabebe Aldub days. His acting definitely improved and was pretty solid overall.Although I did have a problem with how the relationship started in the first half (Alden really was a straight up stalker, wasn't he?), the movie redeemed itself after, not just with how the relationship was ultimately executed, but the execution of the film's central message of how loving yourself over everything else is not necessarily a selfish thing. There's definite chemistry between the two of them, and given how successful the movie is critically and financially speaking, I'm looking forward to their next movie together.Another thing that I really like is that (without getting into spoilers) the movie could had easily ended in a traditional happy ending. They could had easily added a certain scene in the end to do that. But they chose not to, instead delving more into an ending that is whilst bittersweet, much more grounded and admirable. It made the movie had so much more of an impact at the end (and I already really dug the last ten minutes so that was something).Hopefully Star Cinema does keep up this surge of quality and care in its films. I mean, it's not a stunning innovation per se, but it's a noticeable improvement in quality (*coughs* Vice Ganda *coughs*). If there's one thing to be learned from this movie, it's that Filipino audiences do are starting to care on the quality of their local mainstream films, and less on cheap laughs and hollow kilig moments.

‚Äúsabi ko takbo lang, hindi harot!‚Äùit‚Äôs both nice and scary how this movie was so grounded in its portrayal of how class struggle seeps in and plays out into people‚Äôs lives. an all around great cast (LOVED the supporting). kathryn fucking KILLED it with one, and so did alden, if not without his cheesy one-liners but oh well you gotta deal with what you‚Äôre handed with.

Joy: Paano na kapag tinanggal ako, sinong kakayod para sa pamilya ko? Gusto ko nang pumunta ng Canada para sundan ang mga pangarap ko pero kulang pa rin 'yung pera ko. Si nanay, may sarili nang pamilya dito sa Hong Kong pero umaasa pa rin si tatay na babalik siya sa Pinas. Pagod na pagod na ako. Hindi ko naman ginusto 'to. Kahit isang beses lang, gusto kong unahin 'yung sarili ko. Ethan: Binigay sa'yo 'yan ni lord kasi alam niyang malalampasan mo 'yan... Parang ako, God Gave Me You. Me: ay shutah kah----Obviously non-verbatim pero grabe talaga 'yung gigil ko sa character ni Alden kasi ang laki na nga ng problema ni Kathryn pero puro hugot at pickup lines lang binabalik niya. Tuwing bumabanat siya, lumulutang 'yung kaluluwa ko kasi laging may collective "yieeeeeeee" sa sinehan. As always, tibagin na talaga ang mga love teams!! Ang galing ni Kathryn (at crush ko pa rin si Jameson Blake ng slight kahit pilit siya umarte).

Kathryn Bernardo was amazing here. She carried this film from start to end and I am excited for what's next on her career. Alden..on the other hand was just oof. Hello, Love, Goodbye (Review)CGM's farewell note to cinema is a sincere procedural on the measures of familial, eros and self love.Chungking Express and Before Sunrise, anyone? üòÇ I kid.This time, blockbuster director CGM challenged herself, or at least that's what I felt and saw. Apart from the word play and tongue in cheek banters we've all grown accustomed to most of her films, this one hits different. And looks different as welk. From the trailing shots, the hallucinogenic montages and moody shots Ala WKW, this really is quite the departure from the usual Cathy Garcia Molina. And I commend her for that, and obviously giving due props to her (presumably) auteur aspirations, WKW and Linklater, Hello, Love, Goodbye served us feel good familiarity and a bit of philosophy on the power of choice and chance.

Damang dama ko yung pagod ni Joy bilang ofw na walang sawa sa pag suporta sa pamilya niya.Di naman ako ofw pero nakakalungkot lang na delayed ang pangarap natin para sa pamilya, para sa mga mahal natin sa buhay. Sakripisyo talaga, selflessness at lakas ng loob ang puhunan. Tangina. Napaka importante rin talaga na piliin mo muna sarili mo dahil kung hindi, you will lose yourself along the way. Hay. Ang hirap.Kaya para sa mga taong inuna ang pamilya bago ang sarili, tangina, saludo!

The two main actors for this film are big stars and are part of the two most popular tandems in the Philippines (with different partners, though) so I thought this was going to be another teeny-bopper-lovey-dovey movie but I still gave it a go since this newly-formed loveteam intrigued me. I normally am not a big fan of romances but I was so pleasantly surprised by this movie. The marketing was mostly focusing on the love story (because Filipinos usually‚Ä¶

By far, the best Cathy Garcia-Molina movie in my opinion. Surprisingly, Kathryn and Alden definitely have a chemistry, even if they were in different TV stations. CGM really squeezed these two leads to their boundaries to deliver an outstanding movie that is well loved by the fans, the non-fans and the critics. It's not that over-the-top drama but the supporting actors really did all of that. It's a signature CGM move. The supportive, loud, hilarious friends can be quite an eye and ear sore. I know, it is to balance all the drama and stuff but does it really have to be OA (over-acting). The realism of the story is the selling point of this one aside from the lead actors. And it's perfectly portrayed and captured. You can feel the hardships, the pain, with or without experiencing it, it will hit you very hard.A sequel may or may not be needed. But I'm very satisfied on how it ended. Change is good. And we need more movies like this.

I'll be the first to admit that I dismiss Kathryn as an actress simply because:(1) she is half of the Kathniel love team and I just find them so cliche and the typical Pinoy media play just doesn't do it for me anymore(2) I gave her (and Daniel) a chance went I watched The Hows of Us with friends last year and I spent the whole time cringing and regretting my decision to be there(3) I prefer JaDine because I feel they are more genuine and, basically, just more real (I don't dismiss the entire Filipino entertainment industry, fyi)Got dragged into this with friends. I had low expectations given my last movie experience with Kathryn, but I gave it a chance because Daniel wasn't in it and I thought maybe it would be a little better somehow. I like Alden, but I didn't really know how his acting chops were. I was pleasantly surprised by how the film turned out - the plot was honestly a bit predictable but it generally somehow felt more real and refreshing than other Filipino rom-coms (I appreciate this very much, given the number of stereotype Filipino films coming out in the last x years). Alden was great, and I look forward to his next projects. I'm sure he'll get more offers after this. His pairing with Kathryn, I'm sure, has done wonders for his career since this came out.I still think she has a lot of growth maturing to do in terms of her acting (my preference, at least), but seeing this film really changed my opinion of her (at least half of it, I suppose). Definitely still prefer JaDine, and definitely won't be voluntarily watching out for whatever she does next, but she has one less hater in me.

Refreshingly charming, Hello, Love, Goodbye offers a little something new. It is hard to come up with a good romantic drama for a new love-team but Cathy Garcia Molina didn't seem to have a problem creating a new tandem Philippine movie goers would root for. Set in Hong Kong, Domestic Helper Joy played by Kathryn Bernardo works her way to get a visa to leave Hong Kong for good by taking multiple jobs just to get by. She meets a charmingly cute bartender Ethan played by Alden Richards during the first night at her new job and the two manage to become friends and obviously boyfriend and girlfriend. Although it still had the usual formula, the chemistry Kathryn and Alden shared on screen was worth the watch and is a reason to give this movie a chance.

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a classic in the making - the perfect blend of the familiar Pinoy RomCom formula and its modern evolution. It provides an unfiltered and modern OFW story that transcends the glitz and glamour of being in a foreign country, tied together with a love story that could be all too familiar for millennials who are trying to find their place in the world. It‚Äôs the best work yet coming from both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, as well as from directing and writing duo Cathy Garcia-Molina and Carmi G. Raymundo.

saw this latest star cinema drama and i wish i could say i loved it. true, it‚Äôs a marked improvement from the typical rom-coms the studio is famous for but still, despite its spotlight on a subculture of filipino expatriates living as quasi-citizens/residents of hongkong, it is still saddled by the usual storytelling cliches and harrowing contrivances that makes the film less involving and feels a tad bit manufactured. the movie tells the story of ethan and joy who meets in hongkong at a wrong time in their lives ‚Äî she is trying to get away from hongkong and live her dream in canada while he is trying to reestablish his roots and his relationship with his family in the island after a failed relationship in the US. it‚Äôs a good setup but it was not unfortunately sustained when the narrative decided to give more time on cutesy scenes featuring the usual go-to ‚Äúbest friends‚Äù that may be permanently engraved at every screenplay that‚Äôs greenlit by star cinema bosses. and i observed one very sad thing about the movie: i understand that the intention is good but this movie seems to be telling us that families, at least in the vision of the filmmakers, are the modern-day representation of ‚Äútalangka filipino mentality‚Äù ‚Äî in this movie, they seem to get, however unintended, in the way of the dreams, ambitions and happiness of the main protagonists even if the portrayal depicts the age-old child sacrificing all for family. ho-hum.disclosure: i saw the brilliant film ‚Äúthe farewell‚Äù one day before this film and i may have been unfairly influenced by it into expecting that all films could be just as good. this movie was a quick wake-up call that not all movies are good no matter how well-intentioned they are.‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE REVIEW Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film about a domestic helper in Hong Kong; her name is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo). In her last four months in Hong Kong, she met a guy named Ethan (Alden Richards) and at first, she is making him go away because she is finding money for the paper works to be submitted to the Canadian Embassy and not a friend or a relationship. But Ethan persevered and Joy falls in love with him. In this film, we can see the conflict in choosing between love or dream, their own conflicts as a character and the hard work and sacrifice of an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker). First of all, why are there many films coming out in the Philippines about adult rom com? I don‚Äôt know why but all of them is a box office hit! It is well and good that they showed the harsh reality of the life of an OFW; as a family of an OFW, it is sad for us. They are doing the best that they can, but they are still mistreated by their landlords. As big as forgetting to fetch their children at school to as little as forgetting to take the trash out. There are a lot of stories happening at once, but they resolved everything at the end. These stories are a gateway to show the main characters‚Äô internal conflict not just between them. COMEDY IS ON POINT! Just as expected with Joross Gamboa. Not too many and not too few, just the right amount of spice. Also, there are too many clich√© moments, but it worked out well without me cringing. This is one of the Filipino‚Äôs illness when it comes to films; they are too afraid of just letting the visual tell the story. Lines are too much; they somewhat gave away the story before the climax. They did not let the audience think instead they laid it all out for us. I hope that they overcome this fear and let the visual tell the story. I‚Äôm also glad that they used the original artist‚Äôs songs and not just cover it. It sets the mood rather than someone covering it. Lastly, cinematography is meh, okay but I can forgive this one because they shot this entirely in Hong Kong with some parts here in the Philippines. Overall, I give this film a 7/10. Film can be improved by deducting some parts, cut down their lines in half and let the visuals tell the story. Although, acting is on point, I think Star Cinema can squeeze more out of Alden Richards. Cinematography can also be improved by using tripods, stabilizers and a professional drone operator (some aerial shots are jittery). This is your typical ‚Äúlove, dream and family‚Äù story but they added the hardships of being an OFW.

I specifically love the beginning of the film. It didn't feel like you'll be watching a romantic movie. Instead, it shows Joy's life as a DH and her story is just one of the many untold tales of the Filipino workers in foreign countries. Of course Kathryn Bernardo is a phenomenal actress and she immediately caught the audience's sympathy. A loving daughter and reliable older sister. Ethan, on the other hand, is on the other end of the line. A cute bartender with flings and hook-ups on hand. What happens when he met Joy? His life drastically changed. Although it does have some sappy 'romantic' scenes and lines that I felt like sinking to my seat due to undeniable discomfort, this is indeed a romantic movie for everyone and cliches are not cliches if they never work. Anyway, the movie is good. Both actors have great chemistry but then again, I think Kathryn Bernardo could fit well with anyone. Alden Richards has never been more handsome in my eyes. Of course, the funny bestfriends for mere comic relief. Kakai Bautista is hilarious to no surprise. Minus 0.5 star para sa pintong padabog na isinara pero walang tunog.

I love the sincere portrayal of the specific OFW experience of domestic helpers in Hong Kong. The romance wasn't new ground, but still relatively mature within Filipino sensibilities. But the nail in the coffin for this film: the tears wouldn't stop flowing as I thought about my Tita in France who lives her life pretty closely to Joy's.EDIT: Bumping up the rating because I started crying again.

Don't we all need Cathy Garcia-Molina's magic once in a while?This latest offering has that extra special something. Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo have chemistry for days and it didn't feel like they had to work extra hard to show people they have it. The support cast was one of my favorite aspects of this movie- from the friend group, to the family members and to the exes. Maricel Laxa! I live! They swing for the fences and delivered natural performances. The plot was nothing new, but it's really the Pinoy experience in Hong Kong and how these performances stood out that really made adore the film more.

It also shows how this millenia is about thinking for yourself but not forgetting how to look back and cherish people back home.

Taena, iyak ako ng iyak kanina habang kinikilig sa sinehan. (Siguro dahil narin kasama boyfriend)Gusto ko talaga to bigyan ng four stars kasi sobrang refreshing, lagi nlng kasi formulaic local mainstream love stories. Kaso sobrang feel ko na restricted ni Kathryn at Alden sa isa‚Äôt-isa lalo pa nagcamera tricks lang sa kiss (!?!?) Sobrang ganda na sana, sana nag-all-out na. Minsan tuloy nakulangan ako sa sparks nung dalawa, kulang sa connection. Pero hindi naman talaga yung love story part yung nagdala sa movie e, kundi yung mga simpleng patawa, struggles sa pamilya, iyak nung tatay nang makita bunso niya (lalo ako naiyak sa parte na yan), atbp.First time ko pala mapanood si Alden sa kung anupaman and nagtaka ko mas magaling pa siya dito kay Kathryn. Para kasing minsan pilit acting niya, di katulad ni Alden, natural lang. Andun na din yung flaws, tulad ng may mga scenes na alam mong may mas magandang scenario para dun sa gusto nilang mesaage na ipahatid. Also yung mga unrealistic na linyahan. Sana mas ginalingan yung script imbes na cheesy at hindi tagos sa puso. Pero favorite part ko, of course, yung ending, sobrang uncertain ng life. Di tayo sigurado kung magiging successful si Alden sa business niya, makakabalik pa ba si Kathryn at magkakatuluyan pa ba sila. Ultimately, the future is uncertain and we can only do our best.

A surprisingly good but honest Filipino movie about the women who move to Hong Kong to find contract work in the hopes of getting permanent residency, but are unable to fully realize their dreams before then. It's a story about hope, sacrifice, and ultimately finding that little ray of sunshine that can make it all bearable. This is a pretty heavy handed movie that can teach a lot, but also comes with a lot of positivity.
The title says it all.

I didn't expect to like the movie this much, yet here we are‚Äî it deserves all the praise it's been getting. Some dialogues felt a bit clich√© and that acting direction in one scene felt too calculated but the two leads were still great, nonetheless. Kath and Alden played their characters with endearing wit and charm, as their oddities make their interactions raw and believable. What I really like about HLG is that as it goes along it feels riveting on a simplistic scale, it becomes expressive of our own feelings. The theme is on the idea of love (almost didn‚Äôt work for me), but the direction pulls in the audience through its characters‚Äî I am every bit of Ethan and Joy. I work overseas but I have so much to be thankful for that I am not a breadwinner, no responsibilities aside from myself and I have a job that I wanted for myself. Movies are indeed powerful. This made me more appreciative of the life I have now‚Äî it‚Äôs good and a privilege, therefore I should not take it for granted. 6/10

It is a feeling of mixed emotions watching the movie. Once again, we are reminded of the diaspora of Filipinos or OFW's to well off countries such as Hongkong and Canada to look for better paying jobs, no matter what these jobs are . It is sad because of the extreme difficulties encountered by the OFW's. At the same time, I feel thankful that there are jobs and income to support the families back home.Joy's work in Hongkong is hard - her pay is reduced, she gets a part-time job and runs from the Hongkong police because of it. In the middle of this, she sends home money to the Philippines and finds a friend, Ethan. Happiness finds its own source and with Joy, it is in the Central Park where all the "kababayans" provide comfort to one another in the middle of a foreign country with an alienating culture. It is also in Ethan whom she fell in love with.The movie is well directed and masterfully portrays the lives of domestic helpers. Salute to Cathy Garcia-Molina! The script is tight and romantic which clicks with the Filipino audience: "when you talk to strangers, there is no judgement" and " I love you" (witty remark to mean stay away).Finally, Kathryn Bernardo acts very well, she is the next Bea Alonzo. As for Alden Richards, with his handsome face, he can go places in the film industry.

Letter Grade: A (Masterpiece)This is genuinely the biggest surprise in cinematic history for me... now, this might seem utterly ridiculous, for me to call this film a ‚ÄúMasterpiece‚Äù‚Äîand of course, it really isn‚Äôt‚Äîbut man do all the positives about this film outshine the very small qualms I have about this surprsing, genuine, and heartfelt Filipino romance. I really don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs because I was only very slightly intoxicated, or because I‚Äôm a 20 year old gay Filipino in a wonderful relationship with my oh so sweet and loving Brazilian boyfriend, or the chemistry of Alden and Kathryn, or the admittedly cheesy but so emotionally-charged well-weitten dialogue, but this film... this film has made me cry more than any other film I‚Äôve ever seen. More than my ultimate favorites, Lord of the Rings, Cloud Atlas, Spirited Away, Cinema Paradiso, Boy and the World... I literally had to turn away from the screen and bawl on my boyfriend‚Äôs shoulder in the cinema when that last conversation in the pier between Ethan and Joy. I really don‚Äôt know why this film struck me so hard. Maybe it‚Äôs all of the reasons I‚Äôve lifted above. Or maybe this film is also just alright if I revisit it in a while... but wow, I really did not expect this reaction out of me going into this at all. By all means it is definitely not a more technically outstanding film than any of my other favorites, but man I‚Äôd be lying if I said this film didn‚Äôt touch me to my core. What a solid, beautiful film from Cathy. And such nuanced, magnificent performances from Alden and Kathryn. I‚Äôm glad this film exists. Definitely my new favorite Filipino film, overtaking That Thing Called Tadhana by MILES.

Alden Richards‚Äô character, Ethan, is pushy, creepy and problematic. He will continue sending friend requests even if Joy declined several times already. He will make the radio station talk about Joy in public without her permission. He will use another phone to text Joy anonymously. He will act like a police even if Joy is weeping out of fear. He will squeeze through inside a small room knowing that Joy will be uncomfortable. He will continually send ‚ÄúNeed a friend today?‚Äù text messages even if Joy has rejected it so many times. I don‚Äôt know how a Filipino girl reacts to such moves, but if people consider this as ‚Äúnakakakilig,‚Äù there‚Äôs a problem. It almost gave me the same queasy feeling of the stalking problems I saw in Kita Kita and the French film Am√©lie.Hello, Love, Goodbye is at its best when it tells the story of Kathryn Bernardo‚Äôs character, Joy. In some ways, the film manages to outdo similar mainstream Filipino romance films because of Kathryn Bernardo‚Äôs stunning performance and the earnest depiction of OFWs (Overseas Filipino Workers). Bernardo, whose acting holds the film together when it was falling apart, effectively evokes a palpable sense of weariness, discontent, and eagerness to alleviate Joy‚Äôs situation. Actually, I can do without the La La Land love story if the social commentary was strengthened and expounded more. In a similar vein with Sunday Beauty Queen, the film resonates with Filipinos because of its sensible portrayal of what it is like to work abroad in a job you are overqualified in.But Cathy Garcia-Molina‚Äôs picture falls apart as the annoying, melodramatic score continues to play in the background, tackier drone shots are added, and more forced, ‚Äúhugot‚Äù dialogues are delivered by the leads. Sure, this is how clich√©-ridden mainstream Filipino romance plays out. But how I wish we get movies that transcend this generic romantic stratagem. Hello, Love, Goodbye fails to offer something new to romance movies as an art form, and it is disappointing since the OFW story and Joy‚Äôs arc have so much potential.

Filipino romcoms just can‚Äôt shy away with all the cheesiness but as a soon-to-be OFW I feel like I related to Kathryn‚Äôs Joy too much in a way that I HAVE to chase this dream. It‚Äôs all or nothing. And as my departure draws closer, there are moments when I suddenly become scared and I begin to question all my plans. So this movie really spoke to me in that aspect.

Your typical ‚Äútroubled boy falls for a bright young girl‚Äù-themed romance‚Äî ‚ÄúA Walk to Remember‚Äù a.k.a. ‚ÄúGrease‚Äù a.k.a. ‚ÄúSay Anything‚Äù‚Äî Cathy Garcia Molina‚Äôs ‚ÄúHello Love, Goodbye‚Äù discovers puppy love in its purest form. It has plot and spiels topped with cheddar, mozzarella, parmesan, cottage, and blue cheese. Pairing Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards is a genius move. This film showcased how good actor each of them is. Of course, we do not forget the supporting cast because they added extra entertainment and drama. The movie never failed to give a sense of claustrophobic feeling of alienation and loneliness in a developed world‚Äî the very reason why I think portrayal of Maymay‚Äôs character was so realistic. It is a good movie with great acting, average screenplay, and story topped with layers of clich√©s from the romantic drama genre.

MY TWITTER REVIEW:The love story of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) couldn‚Äôt be more formulaic, although I won‚Äôt dismiss its sad factor, but I really couldn‚Äôt care less for it after the movie ended. What the movie successfully conveys is the sacrifices people make to have a better life,...to make ends meet, even if it means being away from the people you love. The family aspect of the movie really got me, it‚Äôs the subplot that actually made me cry. The plight of OFW‚Äôs in this film was executed very well‚Äîsensitively, with a lot of heart.It made a good depiction of how families want to be together but can‚Äôt, the pain and consequences of being away from them, dreams that have to be put on hold and the resilience of OFWs. I loved the movie because of that aspect. Again, as to the love story, not so much.MY FACEBOOK REVIEW:I have to admit that the love story of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) didn‚Äôt charm my socks off. It couldn‚Äôt be more formulaic and to be quite honest, it bored me. (Please don‚Äôt attack me ü•∫)What I loved about it though, and where the film actually succeeds, is its depiction of the life of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW). It was executed very well‚Äîgrounded, sensitive, full of heart. It showed how resilient Filipinos are and how we find humor in everything. That in any way that we can, we always find/create families when we‚Äôre away from our own.The film conveys how sacrifice can be selfless and also selfish. Selfless in the aspect of going away from your loved ones and braving a new world alone to make ends meet and eventually have a better quality of life. Also, that sacrifice can also be selfish, but not the bad kind (? I hope you get it), when it comes to choosing yourself, choosing your dreams instead of always trying to make the people around you happy.The values of this film resonates, especially in every OFW family, how families always try their best to be together albeit it might not actually happen or whenever it does, it‚Äôs going to be a long, long time. That in the end, and this might sound corny, love transcends loneliness, fear or hardship.My favorite scene would be when Kathryn, Kakay and their other friend were watching Vilma Santos‚Äô iconic speech in ‚ÄòAnak‚Äô and Kakay sobbingly asks, ‚ÄúAng pagmamahal ba sa sakripisyo lang naipapakita?‚Äù It‚Äôs a good question, and my answer is NO. Sacrifices are not requirements in love; we don‚Äôt have to sacrifice anything just to show someone we love them but we do it because that‚Äôs how we try to make it work with someone we love and it‚Äôs necessary.

This movie is beautiful, but it does not shy away from those imperfections. No. 1 is it does not know what it is, is it a movie about the struggles of an OFW or a romance film? When you think about it the romance between the two is like just a segway to give us a tearjerker at the end. No 2 is the transitions of scene to scene, I promise you in every 10 minutes of the film I went from smiling straight into being sad. No 3 is that Joy in this movie is hell about not being allowed to breath in this film, from the first 3 minutes of this film she is already the saddest person i seen on a start of film. Lastly, the supporting characters are floating, they have nothing to do in this film, they are flat and one dimensional, the actors and actresses of those supporting characters disappointed me because none of them stepped out of their comfort zone in acting. BUT I can't take the magic of the story and the power of these two. I praise the director of this film because she wrote the most perfect roles for them and there you have the humor which is always perfect. If only the storytelling gets this movie right, it would probably be my favorite Filipino film of all time

"Hindi naman doon nagtatapos ang buhay. Lahat ng gusto mo sa buhay, puwede pa rin, You can be more.‚ÄùHello, Love, Goodbye is one of the great Filipino films I have watched this 2019. I really love the way this movie portraits Filipino values of people working in Hong Kong for their families. Pursuing your own interests/ambitions away from their loved ones while also considering your family's immediate and important needs is one of the most difficult sacrifice everyone can encounter. This movie really thought me how to prioritize yourself more and to support each other's back when it comes to achieving your goals. For Joy and Ethan, distance doesn't matter as long as the roots of their relationship were strong enough.Superb acting performance of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards. Every lines they have delivered really struck me. The drone shots shown in this movie are really amazing. Excellent choice of songs for their soundtracks. Job well done for the people behind this successful movie! ‚ò∫Raw rating: 80

The chemistry between Alden and Kathryn is quite surprising. They were a shade of bomb in this film, showcasing their stunning performances. I did like the first half of the film but it sort of lost its flavor on the latter part because of the catapult from one feel to another. The concept of the film is rather generic but it was overpowered by the provoking realities it laid out that OFWs in HK experience. Nevertheless, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" is a fun-and-feels ride in the face of its flaws.

For the first time I watched a Kathryn Bernardo movie in the cinema, since I'm not a fan, and I must say it did not disappoint me. The movie is a great depiction of the OFWs in Hong Kong, particularly the domestic helpers, through a romance film. Bernardo did great in this movie playing a domestic helper named Joy. Her character was well developed and mature and Bernardo was able to fully portray it with finesse. As you watch the movie and Joy's development you'd feel like you're watching the true pains and hardship that our fellow domestic helpers go through with their work and life in Hong Kong which I think is when the movie is at it's best. As for the romance part of the movie I did enjoy the on screen chemistry of the two leads and how they went through although their story is not as strong as Joy's personal story alone. Richards is fine as the opposite of Bernardo although I do cringe whenever he needs to deliver the cheesy taglish lines which I really don't like in most Cathy Garcia-Molina movies especially that the way those lines was written in the script, it's just that it did not matched with Richard's character Ethan. Overall I did really enjoy this movie from start until the end even though there were some low parts of the movie you can overlook those and find the movie enjoyable and will be happy to recommend it to anyone to see.

Kathryn is immaculate when she is alone and devastated while Alden managed to stretch a very thin character handed to him. A decent watch I must say.

"Hello, Love, Goodbye" is another landmark on Cathy Garcia-Molina's illustrious filmography. While it may not be her best movie, she sprays her piece with hints of realism, grit and realities on the backdrop of being a overseas worker. All the while, she brought it with some weight and optimism that makes it stand out from her recent movies, even though the tone seems derivative from them. It all works because of the performances of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, who are able to carry the levity of their down-to-earth characters. And their chemistry is surprisingly exquisite and wonderfully executed that their solution pays it off. The rest of the movie is filled with neat cinematography, a good pace and a cinematic feeling. And even if the rest of the cast fall on the usual entrapped cliches, it is Bernardo and Richards' rapport that makes "Hello, Love, Goodbye" transcend to its audience. It is one of those Filipino romance movies where I do not hear an over-the-top shouting match. That is at least an achievement.

Cathy-Grace Molina is a definite veteran of the Filipino romance genre, and with Hello, Love, Goodbye, she might have just crafted her most culturally relevant, self-aware, and individually contemplative piece yet. At the very least, it is an authentic portrayal of the plight of the OFWs; But if it weren‚Äôt for the well-written, organic romance between the two lead characters, played endearingly well by both Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo, and with bountiful chemistry to spare, Goodbye may have fallen into the territory of clich√©d conventional Filipino love story. Instead, it is a grounded romance elevated by heart, integrity, and reflection.Take this from someone who isn‚Äôt exactly a fan of the sappy Filipino romance film.

First of all, Grabe saludo ako sa mga cast and staff for a job well done! Sobrang good job sakin yung pagkakagawa ng movie kasi hindi sya narrative. Hindi sya yung typical na romantic films lang kasi meron syang substance and hindi sya puro landi lang. So yes eto lang naman po yung limang natutunan ko sa movie na to. 1. TIME - Kailangan nating pagkatiwalaan yan hindi lang sa love or career. Kasi TIME is everything. Ako lagi kung sinasabi sa sarili ko na ALWAYS ALWAYS TRUST THE PROCESS kasi lahat ng mga nangyayari satin lahat yan may rason hindi man natin gusto yung outcome pero at the end of the day lahat yan may purpose and something more meaningful will be handed out to you. Pasok ito sa lahat ng aspeto ng buhay. Time can change everything and it gives us the flexibilty to grow. 2. SELF LOVE - Sa panahon ngayon napaka hirap i apply to sa totoo lang kasi aminin natin na bigay lang tayo ng bigay sa mga taong mahal natin. We became selfless and nakakalimutan natin na mas kailangan natin i prioritize yung sarili natin hindi dahil selfish tayo, Kundi mahirap lang talagang ma lose natin yung sarili natin in the process. We should know our worth and value kasi at the end of the day sarili lang natin ang makakasalba satin. 3. PLANS - Hindi porket plinano mo eh yun na yun, Based sa experience ko ayoko na talagang nagplaplano or nasasalita ng tapos kasi hindi ko sya napapanindigan sa totoo lang, And dahil dun natutunan kung maging versatile and flexible sa life. Dapat open tayo sa possibilities and mga pwedeng mangyari mapa negative or positive man yan. 4. FAMILY - is everything, Kahit sino satin walang idea kung kailangan tayo kukunin ni lord. Kaya make the most it and make time for your family. Sobrang on point and usapang family sa movie na to. Nabigyan nya talaga ng emphasis. Na kahit ano at sino kapa pamilya mo lang sasalo sayo at the end of the day. So we should be greatful. 5. LOVE - Para po ito sa mga single at sa mga in a relationship. So hindi naman porket single ka eh katapusan na ng mundo tandaan nyo na masaya i enjoy yang ganyang phase ng buhay. Kasi dyan ka mag grogrow as a person and dyan mo mas makikilala ang sarili mo that will make you the better version of yourself. Don't let society dictate you what to do. Just Relax and Chill! :)

I was almost ending this year without watching a Filipino film (which is pretty embarrassing because I‚Äôm a Filipina). But this one, the highest-grossing Philippine film of all time, was the exception.I'm really glad that I have finally seen this. It was truly heartfelt and emotional. Well, I guess for me. 'Cause when you grew up with overseas working parents and became the guardian of your 4 younger siblings at the age of 14, and now that you're an ofw yourself, you just know. You get to empathize with the plight of the OFWs, and as you get fully immersed with Joy's character, you can no longer stop crying. (I so love Kathryn Bernardo, so Yes!)I actually plan to study for a Master's degree soon, so I'm starting to write a concept paper regarding the situations of the OFWs here. Exploring their social conditions, and the stigmas and prejudices they are being confronted. But if things won't turn out the way I want it to be, at least I get to do something really fulfilling on my part.I love you all, pero 'tangina. Pano naman ako?(I love you all but, what about me?)Sabihin nyo ng ambisyosa ako, pero mas mataas dito ang pangarap ko! (You can call me ambitious, but I have dreams bigger than this.)

Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, troopers of this Pinoy rom-com industry, churn out career-best performances held by their own individual wits and charms, and not by whatever makes this weird fish-out-of-water-out-of-country plot ticks, which at times does seem to be some oddly manipulative crushing/stalking maneuvers on Ethan's behalf.But as an immigration/emigration story goes, "Hello, Love Goodbye" weaves around its complexities more deftly than most - love overcomes displacement, but it doesn't vanquish it, even in the most heart-stricken princess stories.

Leave to pursue your dreams, or stay for the love of your life? This is the question that Hello, Love, Goodbye asks us. This latest offering from Cathy Garcia-Molina, best known for her Filipino romantic comedies, is set in Hong Kong. Molina sheds light on the experiences of Filipinos working overseas by following the story of Joy and Ethan, two Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs). We see their lives unfold through the eyes of Joy, a hardworking domestic helper who‚Äôs trying to save money to move to Canada as a nurse, and Ethan, a bartender trying to find his motivation in life.Hello, Love, Goodbye stars two of the Philippines‚Äô biggest names from the two of the biggest ‚Äúloveteams‚Äù‚ÄîKathryn Bernardo (from KathNiel) and Alden Richards (from AlDub). What‚Äôs also surprising is that Bernado and Richards are from rival television networks; in the Philippines, it‚Äôs common for actors to be signed to one network exclusively. Their performance in Hello, Love, Goodbye proves that once in a while, it doesn‚Äôt hurt to break out of your loveteam to grow as an artist. In Hello Love, Goodbye, Bernado graduates from her teen roles and blossoms into a dramatic actress‚Äîa total transformation from her child acting days‚Äîin a tour de force performance. Richards rises to the challenge and exhibits his versatility as an actor, proving why he‚Äôs one of the country‚Äôs matinee idols.To get into their roles, Bernardo was separated from the cast to better empathize with Joy‚Äôs feelings of isolation; after just a week of filming in Hong Kong, she wanted to go back to the Philippines. Richards, on the other hand, lost almost 25 kg to play Ethan. Molina is notorious for her strictness with the artists that she works with‚Äîbut it‚Äôs paid off as they are all household names, and her films have been blockbuster hits.Hello, Love, Goodbye‚Äôs story is not new, yet it provides us with a unique perspective of the realities of being an overseas worker. The film tears away the layers of the OFW experience with sheer intensity. Shifting away from showing the employee-employer relationship found in other films about OFWs, Molina brings her focus to the OFWs themselves, and their families back home.Read the full review here: https://www.cinemaescapist.com/2019/09/review-hello-love-goodbye-movie/

I love the sincere portrayal of the specific OFW experience of domestic helpers in Hong Kong. The romance wasn't new ground, but still relatively mature within Filipino sensibilities. But the nail in the coffin for this film: the emotion wouldn't stop flowing as I thought about my Tita who‚Äôs life pretty closely to Joy's where she came to America as a worker to work to send money back to her family and then fell in love. The movie leans in to the ‚ÄúNovela‚Äù aspect just enough while keeping its feet on the ground. But the real star here is Kathryn Bernado WHO SOARS IN THIS MOVIE! SHE IS A STAR!
