Hello, LoveDo you remember when I told you to watch the trailer of this? You said you've seen the whole trailer, but I just saw the 30 seconds snippet. You said that their story are like ours, but it will be much better because we can decide the ending. My friend even told me that we should see this because she was reminded about us. Now I get it. To be perfectly honest, what we did was a gamble. I was supposed to transfer my love letter to you in a scented paper. We were supposed to see each other tomorrow. I was about to post a picture about us on Instagram. I was supposed to introduce you to my family and friends. We could have made it work, but we didn't. Ethan of my life, I told you multiple times that I wasn't ready, but you keep on and I let my guards down. I told you many times that we can't, but you made it seem possible. I told you that I am going away and that, you're willing to give up everything for me. I told you that you cannot make me choose about you and my career, but I was going to tell you that maybe I can compromise.However, you didn't. I think we both knew that we are both throwing away our lives to the uncertainty of us. I told you that love alone or our affections and words will never amount to the future of us. You said, let's give it a try and take a risk. Little did you know that I've already given a part of me for you. I'm not mad. I promise. I can't blame your premature promises and affirmations, but I should have known better. I've seen and heard those before. I thought maybe this time, it'll work. Hands down, it didn't. Thank God it didn't. I'm trying to be happy now even though I'm still hurting. I just wish that we shouldn't have made those plans together because it is true when I told you that you make me happy and that everything will make sense with you. I'm sorry if I have ever hurted you. I was inconsiderate at times. If my friends would ask me, I will tell them that I did not regret meeting you because you deserve all the love. I will pray for your happiness and health. I hope you're not skipping meals or burning out too much from work. I also hope you get yourself checked. And lastly, He misses you so much. Please, love...come back.I love you. Goodbye.Love, Joy

10 minutes into the film and I am already teary-eyed.Hello, Love, Goodbye is the film that is sure to be successful. It stars actors that has a huge fan base and the storyline is centered on love. I didn‚Äôt think much of it at first and expects it to be just another hugot film. Especially, Cathy Garcia-Molina was directing it. One More Chance 2019, I feel like. But, it‚Äôs different.One, the setting was in Hong Kong. The film made sure to maximize their time abroad by shooting in different locations. Also, they highlighted it in a way that the scenes are almost always outside. The team guaranteed that once the movie is seen, the audiences will be transported to Hong Kong as well. Second, aside from love, the movie dwells on the topic of work. How OFW‚ÄôS work themselves to the bone and how they survive on a day-to-day basis. Kakai Bautista‚Äôs role was the most impactful for me as an OFW. She might not have as much lines at Kathryn Bernardo‚Äôs but when she says it, it rings true. Lastly, the feministic principles of Joy, the heroine. There might be a trend of feministic heroines on Cinema lately like Nadine Lustre‚Äôs on Never Not Love You but it still is special. The way Joy was written was phenomenal. The dialogue was on-point, the justification is there and the way the character grew was understandable. Her decision especially on the Climax point of the movie hurt but it is inevitable. Her line of how the emptiness inside her will never be filled by romantic love alone was poignant. Overall, the movie is great as it arises discussion amongst its viewers. Are you a Joy or an Ethan?

Best and favorite Kathryn acting performance to date. Tagos sa kaluluwa yung mga titig ni Joy, hindi ko mapigilan maguilty sa mga pagkakataong napapagod at tinatamad ako. Also, the scene where Joy and Ethan were on the mountaintop overlooking HK and Joy tells Ethan that she's scared - I felt that. Great ending as well.

The Story of the film depicts the life of a breadwinner modern world which is joy, struggling over dream, love, and passion that she have. These problems are common to be the obstacles of those who has the responsibility of taking part in raising a family where the parents are both unable to.In the film, joy has always been determined to help her family out of poverty that she forgot to live her life according to what she needs and what she wants. When tested by the time and love, she has no choice but to let go of her personal desires and pursue the goal that she has set for the future of a better life with her beloved parents and siblings.In the real world, we don't always get to prioritize ourselves when we have a lot of people counting on us, and during the process of chasing our dreams for them , we missed the moments where we should've live our lives according to our decisions since they will never cross our paths ever again.

One of my favorite filipino movie, A story where love is not just what you give to someone but also to yourself. Marami din naman akong napanuod na movie ng gawang filipino, napaiyak,napatawa,nakarelate and other feeling na pwede pang ma feel. Etong movie na to kakaiba para sakin. Hindi magsama magmahal or pumasok sa loob ng isang relationship, kasi kung tanggap ka or kung kayo, kayo talaga kahit anong mangyari. Dito kasi pinakita ni kathryn na we must never give up on our dreams dahil lang sa nagmahal tayo. kasi karamihan ngayon well hindi ko nilalahat pero karamihan satin mamamayan ganon ang ngyayari. mas pinipili ang love kasi natatakot tayong "minsan" harapin ang laki ng mundo, Diba sabi ni kathryn " Ang laki ng mundo, nakakatakot. " it means there will be more challenges for us to face pero ang sabi ni Alden, " Kaya mo yan." He gave courage to the other kasi alam niyang para sakanya naman, para sa magiging kinabukasan niya at ng pamilya niya.

Typical Garcia-Molina flick that boasts a melodramatic script, unabashed with its sappiness. I could've enjoyed this more if it weren't for the incessant spoon-feeding. On the flip side, kudos to Kathryn who never fails to reel the audience in with her ability for emotional connection.Particular fondness for Cacai Bautista's line:"'Pag ang babae binigay lahat, tanga. 'Pag pinili sarili, masama. San ba talaga kami lulugar, Ate Vi?"

Surprised to see a Filipino mainstream movie whose probably main goal was to introduce a new loveteam, and not be about a love story. Cathy Garcia Molina is a genius for "love team-baiting" everyone into this movie that shows the sad realities of Filipino overseas workers. I'm glad my mom made me watch this on a Saturday night cos I have gained new hope for the mainstream Philippine cinema.
I was truly waiting for this and the film really delivered. Kathryn's performance was on point. The story, the cinematography and the cast gave a film that leaves a mark.

This film is something that I did not expect so much from. I'm a fan of the Kathniel tandem simply because they work and it's something that we're pretty sure would be a hit. So, when Kathryn partnered up with another actor that is not Daniel, I admit I was pretty skeptical. I've watched a couple of interviews until I finally gave in and watched this movie. The film started with an extreme long shot of locations of Hong Kong.‚Ä¶

281. Hello, Love , GoodbyeSebuah film drama percintaan berlatar perjuangan hidup sebagai perantau.Di film ini digambarkan bahwa untuk mencapai mimpi harus melalui jalan yang belum tentu mudah dan menyenangkan atau kita sukai. Selain itu terkadang jalan yang harus ditempuh tidak sesuai dengan rencana dan keinginan kita. Kita juga akan dihadapi pilihan yang mungkin tidak mudah untuk memutuskannya.Dari segi cerita saya menyukainya, tidak terlalu opera sabun. Aktingnya juga natural.Saya menyukai endingnya.

ok lang siya, mostly made me think about the gap between going there as a tourist and being there for ""~~menial~~"" work... the past two trips i've had always made me sad-pensive about this, especially when my family wanted to eat in the jollibee (sorry) in mk and it happened to be on a sunday. or the time when i ate in jollibee central and the filipina working the register was cursing the hong konger manager bc he was being a dick and started slamming shit when all she did was ask if something was still available (they were closing in an hour), saying "parang wala kang nanay" ......but i'm now going off on a tangent hereanyhow ty gateway for always screening films even months after the premiere p.s. tanga tanga naman nito ni ethan charotttt may character development naman

Generic story that really just used domestic helpers as a plot device. Not much chemistry between Alden and Kathryn but love that they‚Äôre exploring outside of these caging mechanisms called love teams. Good acting by Kathryn but nothing more than what we‚Äôve already seen her do (The Hows of Us). Wasn‚Äôt impressed by Alden.

I kind of loved this. It‚Äôs also sort of funny how this is the only time you could really feel the star-turn arrival of Alden Richards despite his present celebrity status. Greenbelt 3.
Hindi ko rin alam bakit ko siya inulit the next day. But it was even funnier, and more painful the second watch.Gateway.
walang kwenta mga lalake

did some scenes get me emotional or am I just really sad when I watched this?idk, but some points I can conclude:‚Ä¢ I like the social commentary about the OFWs and about Joy wanting to reach her dreams so bad. there's a scene where I cried (just a tear or two) bc in that part, Joy was venting everything to Ethan abt her dreams and wanting to be selfish for once. and I felt that so bad. or maybe I was just too sad right before I watched it?‚Ä¢ It was well-acted, especially by Kathryn. I think she really peaked with this one without Daniel Padilla lol. it's actually a breath of fresh air for her and for the audience. also, I was surprised by Alden's acting. it was pretty nice actually. ‚Ä¢ some parts were really cringy (or cheesy) but bearable. afterall, it's a romance anyway.
Hirarkiya ng pag-ibig: "Kung mahal mo 'ko, bakit pinapapili mo 'ko?" Aligaga. Obligasyon. Taning. Pangarap.
Ilang beses kaya nag-ayos ng cap si Alden sa pelikulang to? May nagbilang ba?

didn't expect there was going to be a good chemistry between them; at first, i thought they would only look good as siblings but this movie proved me wrong. anyways, the movie serves as a window for us to see how the filipino domestic helpers abroad work really hard despite of all the things they left behind. their comedic timings are smooth yet made me feel validated. It's a millennial love but is pragmatic and not pretentious
damn... this really made my feelings go upside down and im still so affected by everything about this film.

Andaming sobrang weird na details pero pwede lang naman dedmahin. I guess sayang lang sya kasi it was promising, it couldve told a story that spoke more pero all than in exchange for a mediocre love story.Thankful lang din ako kasi si Alden yung naging on-screen love interest ni Kath, kase mas less cringey sksjsjsj. And also Joross?? Sobrang cringey nung mga lines nya lol.I usually dont have much expectations for Cathy Garcia Molina's films, and also I hate it when a film emotionally blackmails me into liking it, pero this one i really liked.

My professor in Introduction to Global Society class in DLSU just used this film to discuss migration. Here are some of the points we talked about after viewing the film:- Migration has become less of a choice but a necessity- There are different types of migration, such as labor (for work) and marriage, as shown in the film- Migration is driven by economic factors- There is a cost/benefit analysis whenever someone migrates- OFWs are perceived as ‚Äúwell off‚Äù just because they are in another country- Underemployment is common. Better to be underemployed in another country than in the Philippines.- There is a certain identity maintained by the Filipino diaspora; there is always a hope to come back homeNay, may uwi po akong broccoli at pansit! Nay!!!!
naappreciate ko yung acting ni kathryn dito more than ever ‚ù§Ô∏è
See how refreshing things get when we shake things around once in a while.
napanood ko to during theatrical run nakalimutan ko lang i-log pero ayun bumalik lang yung galet ko! weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee baket ba kasi kailangan gawin love story nakakatanga

It's your typical Filipino movie scenario where boy meets girl, they fell in love with each other, at the near end of the movie they have this big fight/misunderstanding, and in the end, they either make amends and be together or they continue on with their single lives. Nothing new, the same old same old, recycled love story that has been told numerous times in the past. Though Kathryn and Alden were good in this movie, its the story itself that lacks a new perspective. I mean it is soooooooooo predictable from the start, this scenario of a love story was already even told from a local TV series but it's a shorter version of it (Hell, I can't even remember the title of that series anymore)!

What I love about Hello, Love, Goodbye is its effective portrayal of the hardships and lives of OFWs. Kathryn Bernardo is really effective in her role as a selfless domestic helper and I'm surprised that she and Alden Richards has chemistry onscreen. I like the montage in the film's opening sequences and Bernardo's opening narration. I still cringe the cheesy lines, the usual family conflicts in Star Cinema's films and the overdone scoring. Nevertheless, this film is still good. But nothing still beats Milan when it comes to showcasing OFW hardships and trials abroad. Claudine was excellent there and I think that it's a masterpiece.

"I don't love you."What could've been a typical Star Cinema rom-com turns out as a less-typical one. There are cheesy tropes that are in the same realm and this is far from an indie rom-com spectacle. However, what made this different is how the story revolves around on dreams and choosing to grow together even when apart from each other.At first, I found the Alden and Kathryn team-up quite odd and don't fit well but as the film progress, their chemistry blossoms and the dialogues between grow on you. Kathryn definitely carried the film and it felt as if Alden is the support that completes the film with her.The overall heart of the film is pretty much there and makes this stand out from the rest of the Star Cinema rom-coms in the 2010s.

Tentang pergumulan hidup, tentang mengejar impian dan tentang cinta. Dunia tak sekadar hitam dan putih bagi para pekerja migran filipina di Hongkong, ada segala kerumitannya di sana. Film drama romantis terbaik tahun 2019 imo.. most definitely in my top 10 list.

Hello, Love, Goodbye‚ÄîGarcia-Molina's latest‚Äîis overstuffed, overscored, and relies too much on unrealistic dialogue to bring its story to life....yet I was so smitten by it, like my heart is going to burst at any moment. Weird. Hmmm
It's so refreshing to see Kat with someone other than Daniel. Alden in this movie is a revelation. The chemistry of the leads is impeccable. I was bawling.üò≠

Best part of the film was the cinematography and how it actually uses Hong Kong and its streets, buildings etc. as a storytelling element and not just promo for the film. Solid shots and color grading. The plot was refreshing considering the generic romcom Pinoy film. The writing was good but it would‚Äôve been better with less of the cheesy or fanservice type stuff. Solid acting and interesting and entertaining characters. Reminded me of Kita Kita but 10x better.

the acting was *chef‚Äôs kiss*. the score was perfect. the screenplay slightly corny but ON GOD would make you tear up!!!i could relate to joy. i would, in a heartbeat, choose my dreams for once over a guy who planned it all out for supposedly the both of us.

Hello, Love, Goodbye catapulted itself as not only the highest grossing Filipino film of 2019, but also of all-time. Unlike previous title-holders, this acclaim is well-deserved because the film is actually good. Two overseas Filipino workers (OFW), Joy and Ethan, meet in Hong Kong and fall in love. However, Joy is planning to leave the city soon to pursue her dreams elsewhere. Meanwhile, Ethan is about to become a permanent resident and is at the cusp of building a long-term life there. What‚Äôs most notable about Hello, Love, Goodbye is how it immerses us into the OFW experience ‚Äî the daily hustle, the homesickness, and the impermanence of it all. Not that the story is any different from Anak or Sunday Beauty Queen, but the film managed to go deep into the lives of domestic helpers and Hong Kong residents with so much authenticity and breadth. And then there‚Äôs the pairing of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, which propels the film‚Äôs dramatic stakes to even greater heights. Both are completely believable not only as lovers, but also as people trying to make their families proud. The film‚Äôs overarching theme of ‚Äúchasing after your own ambition‚Äù will surely resonate with everyone ‚Äî that being in a relationship doesn‚Äôt mean that you have the same goals in life and that ambition is a personal thing. Every once in a while, we get a Star Cinema film that breaks out of the rom-com mold and superficial happy endings. I am absolutely floored with how the film ended. Even more so that they didn‚Äôt attempt to reverse the ‚Äúgoodbye‚Äù with an ‚Äúafter 10 years‚Äù epilogue.

Being a Filipino working overseas feels suffocating, which this film manages to execute that feeling perfectly thanks to the performances of Kathryn Bernando and Alden Richards.The reason why people love this film wasn't because of the romantic moments between Bernando and Richards, but because of how the film depicted the unglamorous life of an OFW.

After bringing more misses than hits, it's safe to say that HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE is the film that finally gets Cathy Garcia-Molina back on her feet to once again captivate the Pinoy cinephile's attention thoroughly. As a celebrated contributor to modern Philippine cinema with her iconic Star Cinema features from previous years, she seems to have lost her touch with her being inclined on quantity-over-quality style of releasing films. 2018's 'The How's of Us' which starred Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo may have worked for some, but to others, it all still felt trite and stale as that still felt like a star vehicle than a supposedly enthralling story-centric piece about young romance.Molina must've listened to the critics because her 2019 offering is quite special for a lot of things ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì all of which make it a solid venture into new horizons for the filmmaker that hopefully, she'll continue to explore to continue an exciting streak of films potentially started by this one. If one were to take it a step further, it's also a bold film, really for what it shows and tells to the audience as a mainstream release that makes it slightly unconventional and powerful. What makes it so is the strength of the discourse that astonishingly, marvelously overpowers that of the Star Cinema rom-drama formula that Molina has always gripped onto. It seems to have came at an opportune time, too, considering the state of Hong Kong during the time of its release which makes it a film of considerable significance that brings enlightenment to a wide audience about the OFW experience overseas. The film can work and be enjoyed both ways, and that's really where the magic can be found, tasted, and adored. As a social commentary piece about the lives of OFWs in Hong Kong, it's fascinating and moving specially because of how the characters of Joy and Ethan are written with specificity where the drama is stressed and is made impactful. And so, that brings us to the other side of the film that makes the romance that they try to invigorate worth buying into knowing their stories that can pretty much be anyone's. Looking deeper into those two facets of the film, it seems like everything here works fine and well, and indeed it does that it feels like a charm so unbelievable in how it is conceived.Though the film may still fall under the trappings of Cathy Garcia-Molina's films, such as the sappiness of the romance or the movie-like dialogue that takes away an amount of authenticity, they aren't huge hindrances to the film being well-formed. Molina doesn't merely make it all feel like a star vehicle for Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards after all since there's meat given to the characters they play courtesy of co-writers, Carmi Raymundo and Rona Co. It may be unexpected, but believe it or not, the screenplay of the film is astonishingly rich even if the direction isn't as masterful as one would like it to be. The actors really work from that, bringing great stuff for us to commend, absorb, and feel; almost Even with the flaws resting in it, there's no way for one to not be won over by what this film packs. A love letter to OFWs not only in Hong Kong, but all over the world who sacrifice themselves for love in different ways, it rightfully deserves to be seen and embraced as a new classic for the memorability of how it converses, which shows its profound dedication and respect to those it represent onscreen with immense accuracy. It's honestly the kind of Star Cinema film that you'd hope to be made more often; tempered, substantial, and resonant ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì a film that knows how to reach its audience in ways that don't feel too compromised and feeble in their attempts.

Sobrang buong-buo ung character ni Joy at natuwa ako na nabigyan ng highlight din ang struggle ng atin mga kababayan na nagpapakahirap sa ibang bansa. Mahusay din si Kathyrn Bernardo, na nagdala ng buong pelikula. Sana di lang napwersa yung half-baked love story at feeling ko hindi pa din earned ni Ethan yung growth na nakuha niya sa huling part ng pelikula.

Basically, konflik & dilema kayak gini udah familiar sejak nonton series On The Wings of Love (dari Filipina juga), tema besarnya hampir sama, jadi gak terasa spesial lagi. Hanya saja, di sini Kathryn Bernardo unggul dari segala aspek, sedangkan lawan mainnya terasa sulit untuk keep up.Dan, lagu2 pinoy kok enak2 banget siiih?

As of now this is the top-grossing box office hit in the Philippines and honestly I'm not mad. Even if it was set in Hong Kong everything about this film speaks to most Filipinos. I highly recommend it.

This isn‚Äôt a groundbreaking OFW film, but it is a very specific one, and it‚Äôs truly the details that make it potent - along with what‚Äôs perhaps one of the most fully-realised female characters in recent Philippine cinema, brought to life by an impressive Kathryn Bernardo.

isang nakakatuwa at nakakalungkot na pelikula na nakabalot sa isang klasik cliche filipino rom com na tungkol sa buhay ng mga ofw natin na nakabase sa hongkong may magandang mensahe at mga tema na maayos na nailahad simple lang ang istorya girl meets boy tas boy keeps disturbing the girl even if she blatantly rejects him already mejo hindi ko lang natripan yung ilan sa mga katangian sa karater ni alden richards pero overall tingin ko nabawi naman natuto naman siya sa hule at saludo ako sa ending dahil yun ang siyang nararapat at maganda ang sinasabi dito na sa tunay na buhay e hindi magiging perpekto ang lahat at hindi palaging happy ending pero ang pagtanggap natin sa riyalidad na ito ang siyang tama at makabubuti sa atinmahusay na inilarawan dito ang mga pinagdadaanan ng ating mga modernong bayani sa araw araw nila maski sa hirap sa trabaho ginhawa sa piling ng kapwa nila pilipino pagsuko gawa ng lungkot pagsisisi sa mga maling desisyon, pagsasakripisyo nilang dulot ng pagmamahal at sa hindi nawawalang simpleng kaligayahan ng mga pinoyhindi ko alam kung okay ba saken yung pagiging madalas na pagtaglish ng dayalog, siguro mas gusto ko lang na purong pilipino kasi nga pelikulang pilipino to pero dahil ganun din ako madalas magsalita dulot ng kasanayan e madali ko naman tinanggap tsaka nasa ibang bansa sila normal naman na ganon, mas magustuhan ko lang ng konte siguro kung pinanindigan yung pagkapilipino sa ganung pamamaraan.magaling ang pagarte ng mga bida lalo na sa mga eksenang dramatik ayos din na ramdam na ramdam ang kemistri nilang dalawa may ilang istorya lang na hindi masyadong nabigyan ng tuon at hindi nabigyan ng magandang konklusyon tingin ko dapat mas binawasan yung mga romantic scenes kapalit ng mga yon pero sino ba naman ako para magsalita tingin ko lang naman yon ang titulo nga naman ng pelikula e hello, love, goodbye alam ko naman kung ano pinasok ko sa pagnuod netosa pangkalahatan e sobrang enjoy naman tingin ko ang pinakapuso ng pelikula ay nasa kanilang mga pamilya at sekondarya lamang ang kanilang pagibigan, isang kwento na karapatdapat na naisapelikula at karapatdapat na maibahagi at mapanood ng marami at yun nga ang nangyaribest moments para saken e yung mga solid na comic relief ng mga side karakters tulad nung mga linyang mader packer ako yung manager dat sakin ka nagpapaalam stuckroom at marami pang iba

"Ang choice para lang sa may pera" (Choice is only for those who have money)It makes me so happy this rom-com is the highest grossing Filipino film of all time. Cathy Garcia-Molina obviously knows how to make a rom-com filled with the genre's tropes & make it sing. Turning it into a love story between two intergenerational Overseas Filipino Workers in Hong Kong who are bound by the struggle to survive under late capitalism & the sacrifice they made to leave their families for another country to give them better life gives Ethan & Joy's love story more weight & poignancy. The fact that it mostly shows the usual places Filipino domestic workers would go to in Hong Kong, trying to cram as much details & stories about the OFW experience in without torpedoing the plot, & holding off on the country's tourist spots until it mattered speaks to its priorities. And goddamn this might be Alden Richard's finest performance yet & Kathryn Bernardo is fucking fantastic.Someone in the Third World Cinema Club podcast mentioned that it's fascinating to watch this now, since it was shot before the ongoing protests in Hong Kong. It's like a time capsule from the point of view of Filipinos with the typical Star Cinema sheen.

Typical love story cinema's in Philippines are intoxicated with. Fresh in the sense that Kathryn Bernardo gets a new screen partner to play with in Alden Richards and that works out almost for the better, as her and Daniel Padilla are almost a tired married couple after teaming for so long. The story focuses on OFW, filipinos working abroad, here Hong Kong, and the tough situation they face a they try and build a better life for themselves and their families, and how romance help ease the desperate situation. On a positive it doesn't get cheesy, but by the end it doesn't really generate the emotional kick that was almost built-up. Still a pleasant watch.
'I'm sorry i made you feel you had to apologise just because you have dreams''i will work hard to deserve to be in your future'

The right amount of kilig and drama can separate a romantic movie from the rest. Hello, Love, Goodbye is a romantic drama that surprisingly doesn't fall prey to the mainstream formulaic love stories we've seen in the past. It's not peppered with cliches. It's relatable without it trying too hard. This love story of Ethan and Joy is a non-toxic relationship that's easy to get behind. The Hong Kong backdrop and the chemistry between the leads made this movie all the better. For moviegoers like me who's long given up in the mainstream romance movies the industry has to offer, this is certainly a refreshing treat.P.S. Can't believe I'm months behind everyone else.

I love how the movie give more empowerment for the woman. The struggle, the trust, their stress management. Even the story of her parents. Journey of her life. How she make her own plan for the future. How making a choice for ourselves can be a big dream. At first I thought it will be cliche love story. But it is more than that.
Hello, Love, Goodbye is an empathetic and heartfelt tribute for the OFW struggle with strong, immersive performances from Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo.

Nagandahan ako sa pelikula. Nagandahan ako sa cinematography at kulay ng pelikula. May feels na mala-Never Not Love You meets Milan at other OFW-related themes itong HLG. Nakakakilig din dahil swak ang chemistry nila Kathryn Bernardo at Alden Richards. Tailored-fit role kay Alden ang role niya bilang Ethan kaya naman ito ang best performance niya so far sa pelikula. Sa una, parang miscast si Kathryn pero habang tumatagal at nakikipagtagisan ng pag-arte kay Alden ay lalong parehas silang hindi nagsasapawan kumbaga nagbibigayan. Isa pang kapansin-pansin sa pelikula ay ang supporting actors tulad na lang ni Jameson Blake. (Matatandaang naging kontrobersyal si Jameson dahil sa "shout-out" statement na work of art sa Twitter.) Napatunayan naman ni Jameson ang galing niya sa 2 Cool 2 Be 4gotten. Magaling at bagay siya bilang kapatid ni Ethan. Ganoon din ang mga gumanap na kaibigan ni Joy na sila Lovely Abella, Kakai Bautista at Maymay Entrata. Nagulat ako na kasama sa pelikula si Maricel Laxa bilang ina ni Joy.

AMC A-ListA Filipino movie where two Filipinos living in Hong Kong meet and fall in love.This was more than a typical rom-com with alot of the film dealing with how hard it is to be living and working so far from home and family. The two leads had great chrmistry. Very enjoyable.

I was actually surprised that their tandem worked. I was worried at first cause I thought Alden was going to be vastly compared to Daniel Padilla but he really did a great job portraying Ethan. He surpassed all my expectations. He did really well. As for Kathryn, of course, who wouldn't love Kath? Pretty face and her acting skills was beyond amazing. Storywise, I LOVED THE CONFLICTING QUESTION whether you will choose commitment and be with someone you truly love or choose to follow your dreams and for once in your life, pick yourself over others (?) It's something that the viewers can relate to. The only problem is with me cause I kept on comparing it to The Hows of Us which is not really necessary. Dunno what's wrong with me lol. I can say that this film is something different compared to other pinoy romantic dramas. It was also good that this film informed its viewers about the hardships and struggles every OFW experience just to give back to their loved ones back home.

I cried laughing at some of the cheesiest lines here, they were just too much. But I was surprised at how moving this story is! Their love story feels like a La La Land imitation, but it‚Äôs given extra layers in its relation to family and immigration. It‚Äôs more complex than the average tearjerker. Alden‚Äôs performance is hammy as fuck but it saves the movie from insufferable melodrama. Kathryn Bernardo really makes this movie. I watched this to laugh but I ended up caring.My only major issue is a lot of scenes repeat the same story beats. It‚Äôs arguably comical for characters to have the same arguments over and over, but it stagnated portions of the story. I‚Äôd say if it were 10-15 min shorter, it would‚Äôve felt more efficient with its time. Gorgeous film though, and worthy of its title as the highest-grossing Filipino film.

Is it wrong if this movie‚Äòs spotlight on Hong Kong makes me romanticise Hong Kong more from the view of a foreigner?The movie poster caught me but the synopsis made me watch it as I am interested in discovering more narratives of domestic helpers. As an Indonesian, I learned a lot more of Filipino words which are surprisingly similar to my language, such as ‚Äòbangon‚Äô and ‚Äòutang‚Äô, so that was interesting and made me curious to learn the language. As a woman, I hate the fact that body-shaming was absorbed into a couple of jokes during some scenes, notably Miss Central 2019. As a nobody who is not qualified to give any critics on film but will do it anyway, I would say that this movie centres around the life of one domestic helper which is pretty illustrative but not of the domestic work itself. It disentangles a bunch of issues which may probably be central to some women foreign domestic helpers. If there is anything that I would like to underline is that Joy helps Ethan and not the other way round. If you cannot see something as simple as that then I do not know what else to say except to recommend you watch the movie again. This kind of movies that reinforces the idea that men are allowed to force the love out of a responsible, ambitious, and bright young lady just because that lady is too arrogant to love is just... disgusting. We need to stop praising men for doing the bare minimum and stop romanticising creepy, forced love-lines.

This is a story that hits close to home because of my mom.I don‚Äôt know the details of what my mom went through working also as a domestic helper in Hong Kong. What i do remember though is something she said in passing; that she would cry every night because she was away from me. I never thought of my mom leaving me in the Philippines when i was younger as something easy. I knew it was hard, i just didn‚Äôt know HOW hard. I respect and love my mom so much and knew she did a lot for me but this film made me see things differently. That respect and love blinded me, it never crossed my mind to really think about what she went through and now to think that she did all of that for me fills me with emotions i can‚Äôt even begin to explain. I‚Äôm so thankful but also so sorry. I just hope i‚Äôm able to repay even just half of what she has given me and she has and continues to give me everything.

I read somewhere once that flying makes you more prone to crying but I think that even at ground-level, this movie would have made me cry. On the surface, it looks like your typical Filipino romcom. Guy meets girl, one of them dislikes the other initially, the other person is interested and tries to win their affection by being both pabebe yet persistent, a montage ensues, and as much as one party tries to fight it, they eventually fall in love (chAr).I remember seeing the trailer for this sometime last year and wanting to watch it because it looked promising. While the movie does fall trap to some of the cheesiness and tropes (read: Ethan's backstory) that make the aforementioned typical local romcom weak, it manages to bring a depth to its characters, including l Hong Kong itself, that usually escapes mainstream blockbusters.This is exemplified in Joy's character. I've been a Kathryn Bernardo fan since grade school (hello Mara Clara) but this is probably her best performance to date. We are thrown headfirst into the demands of Joy's life and her routine, the pacing of which I really enjoyed. Duty to family, the dichotomy between practicality and passion, and the price of following your dreams take on a new meaning in her situation. You can't help but root for her and (if you're like me) want to throw a shoe at Ethan. The movie never outright asks you for sympathy. Instead, it paints an honest picture of things as they are for so many OFWs in Hong Kong. It leaves the viewer instead to decide how they feel about not just the characters' situations, but also the very systems that birth and perpetuate them. Glad I was finally able to catch it! I didn't manage to finish the whole thing but am hoping to during quarantine

Hmm, sounds like "Three Words from Forever". Straightforward as this title is, whatever the complications and heartbreak in Cathy Garcia-Molina's latest romantic tragedy, they can't be any heavier than the story that has to be behind Kathryn Bernardo not playing opposite Daniel Padilla. No, I'm sure their marriage is as annoyingly adorable as ever, especially since this film doesn't set a good tone for them seeing other people, onscreen alone. Bernardo plays a free-spirited domestic worker in Hong Kong, with a diverse network of friends that - don't worry, Filipino conservatives upset about an onscreen couple not being married offscreen - isn't too diverse. She naturally hits it off with a handsome fellow Philippines expat, an ambitious bartender looking to lay some roots down in the city our woman can't wait to get the heck out of. As the two begin to look to their seemingly temporary friendship to help them weather the Hong Kong hustle, it becomes clearer that they have ideas to spend their lives together, and extremely different ideas about how to. As the title plainly tells you, this story won't work out, but it is charming, way to a fault.I mean, this is clearly just another trite and sappy romantic-comedy-drama, of little consequence and even less surprise, with a runtime of two hours. This doesn't want to be "just another", as it lives up to its title by methodically examining the process of a potentially doomed romance with the intimacy and draw of a prestige love story. There's more potential on paper than you'd think, but of course it's all hijacked by overwrought rom-com sensibilities, especially with bouncy pacing and gratingly corny, relentless music. Jessie Q. Lasaten's score sucks, and it's just about omnipresent throughout an authentically paced drama to bring out the inauthenticity of its melodramatic situations, frilly farce and general genericism. The script doesn't help with its quirky sense of humor and hearty or histrionic breakthroughs, all cheapening substance that is just full enough to water down that punch-up. That script may only feel obligated to pander to the lowest common denominator, but it sits between the tritest of romantic melodramedies and the most cloying of aesthetics. The average rom-com viewer may also get bored with the runtime, so of course I find more compelling than the average rom-com.There's certainly a unique enough romance in the gorgeous, ever-bustling backdrop of Hong Kong explored extensively as its own character. This scope is more than enough to liven up this intimate love story... but just to be safe, let's overshoot the environment, overwork the editors, and overplay an oppressively corny score. There's nothing refreshing or challenging about this shameless fluff piece, but its themes are a little more grown-up than usual, more frank about the chore of reconciling romantic interests with personal ones. Histories of failures and potentials for success are heavily debated and approached in this two-hour dual-character study, at a methodical clip that may bore certain viewers without the fallback of zanily colorful supporting characters. They bring some laughs, and texture the personalities of lead characters who are spoiled by their own, more mundane humor and quite a few humiliatingly cheesy bearings of soul. Besides that, their motivations and relationship turns are thoroughly, even complexly drawn, and tightened under the solid chops and crisp chemistry of the beautiful Kathryn Bernardo and the handsome Alden Richards. This takes the time to build a genuine human drama, but it's squandered on meager fluff.Between the ready-made claptrap and the meanderingly thoughtful romantic dual-character study, the former pretty much prevails on grating music, style, comedy and melodrama, with enough entertaining sprawl in the lavish Hong Kong setting, more colorful characters and endearing flair, and enough real nuance in the characters, their relationship and the performances, to make Cathy Garcia-Molina's "Hello, Love, Goodbye" a touchingly heartfelt, just as abrasively disingenuous romantic melodramedy.2.75/5 - Fair

This is a movie that normalizes and romanticizes harassment, gaslighting, and manipulation and justifies it by having the antagonist having had his heart broken by another woman too. so it‚Äôs misogynist as well.the tragedy here is that there is a much better story buried here about joy‚Äôs life working as a domestic helper in an all woman household, a cousin who is having a more difficult time adjusting to life as an OFW, and a mother who was essentially sold off into marriage by her father who chooses to stay with her abusive husband regardless. all of that is ignored for a mediocre love story that doesn‚Äôt add anything to the genre nor give a good example of what being in a relationship should be.

Re-watched Hello, Love, Goodbye. Sana we all have Joy's courage to choose ourselves at long last, 'no? Anyway, the film's brilliance isn't about Joy and Ethan's romantic relationship. It's how the film showed, using the perspective of Joy, the plight of the OFWs in Hongkong. It stripped the usual Hongkong image as a vacation destination by using the DH life montage as a background. Realistic. Authentic. We need more of this kind to let us understand more how the Filipino diaspora is a socio-political issue we need to address. How the "bagong bayani" suffers, not just from homesickness, but from social inequities.

Meh. The only thing new about this Star Cinema romance is the ending ‚Äî it opens the story up to a sequel. Movies of this kind from the movie giant would always end with a definite closure. Perhaps they‚Äôre looking forward to another partnership with the actor who was loaned from another network for this movie.The movie was mostly noisy. It had the most noisy and annoying sidekicks ever. They all follow the typical formula of sidekick friends telling the main protagonists what and how to feel. I especially dislike one of the lady friends - the one with the thick Visayan accent. The accent was obviously put on as some form of comedic relief. But it was not funny; it was extremely annoying. No real Visayan talks like that. Alden Richards - it‚Äôs my first time watching him in a full-length anything. He works in a TV network that I hate, so I‚Äôve never really seen him act that much. Anyway, I‚Äôve been trying to figure out what‚Äôs different about his face. He‚Äôs handsome, for sure; but I just couldn‚Äôt put a finger on that one thing that‚Äôs different until I saw him in this movie. I know it now ‚Äî he has a very shallow, barely there philtrum! Maybe from the years of wearing braces, his upper lip flattened out?Anyway, Kathryn was good. Almost made me cry again in one scene. But then Alden spoke, so there. Don‚Äôt get me wrong; I don‚Äôt hate the boy. I was just really so intent in observing him in his every scene, trying to figure out his face situation.What I would change about this movie: Get rid of all those annoying sidekicks. Star Cinema can do better.

I prepared myself for everything but disappointment.This film was recommended to me by several people and so I‚Äôve decided to find a perfect time to watch it without distractions. I wish I did not.Joy was such a strong character which Bernardo was just enough to portray. I could imagine other actresses who would be able to give justice to the same role. I was not surprised at how Bernardo was able to incredibly pull off that ‚ÄúWhat if I choose not to stay?‚Äù scene. She does those kinds of scenes really well in any film.Ethan, on the other hand, was a bad character and Richards was not able to make it any better.I hated how they had to used ‚ÄúAnak‚Äù to emphasize the struggles of OFWs. Maganda na sana. I thought for a moment that it was a good take on the lives of DH. It just went a little overboard.Overall, I wish I just watched it the first time I thought of doing so. Tinabi-tabi ko pa for a ‚Äúspecial time‚Äù, hindi naman pala as good as how it‚Äôs promoted.

With unrelenting chemistry and superb acting from its two leads, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" turns out to be an outstanding romance drama film experience. Against the backdrop and introspective of our country's modern day heroes, the OFWs (Overseas Filipino Workers) specifically domestic helpers in Hong Kong, the film was able to bank on even more emotions than expected.Life in Hong Kong is not easy more so for the domestic helpers who are unable to improve their lives even if they wanted to. One of these domestic helpers is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) who has wants to leave Hong Kong and find a better life in Canada as a nurse. But unfortunate circumstances have prevented her from attaining this life-long dream. Ethan (Alden Richards) is a bartender and has a few years left before he can be a permanent resident in Hong Kong. Both meet one fateful night and while they do not fall instantly in love, Ethan's persistence eventually wins Joy's heart. But their polar opposite circumstances and dreams will make the decision to continue with their relationship a difficult one to make."Hello, Love, Goodbye" does enough to make it one of the better romance drama films we have seen. How it accomplishes this is by pretty much making outstanding work on the basics. First and foremost, the central characters of Ethan and Joy were well-written and well-scripted. Both characters had deep-seeded personal issues that were not only central to the film's main conflict but grounded and believable. The script was mostly great having its fair share of emotional one-liners and witty banters but we have to admit, it went a little too cheesy in some scenes. Beyond that, both characters had great actors and performances behind them that gave these characters much life and much justice. Additionally, the main narrative was well-written. It felt fresh and had a lot of unexpected twists, turns, and surprises along the way. The ending was satisfying without spoiling much. It also presented a basic look into the stark reality of the OFW domestic helpers in Hong Kong. However, we felt that the film failed to establish more emotions on this introspective. While it had some unnerving revelations about the domestic helper life, most of these have been tackled better in other films previously. What surprised us most though if the film's cinematography. It's a given that Hong Kong is a beautiful city to begin with but the camera work here impressed us. Overall, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" is a great romance drama film worth your time and one heck of a dramatic film at its core.Source: www.reeladvice.net/2019/09/hello-love-goodbye-movie-review.html

The film had a lot of technical flaws and pass√© comedy injected into it (fat jokes in 2019? really cathy?). It would have worked better if it hadn't been for the half-baked (arguably unnecessary) romance plot but who are we kidding? This is Star Cinema.However, very un-Star Cinema-esque is its approach to the struggle of our OFWs and I respect it for that. Joy's character is solid and human, the driving force of the film despite the cringey corniness of her "romance". Kathryn deserves all the praise and her chemistry with Alden was surprising, especially in the early days of their ~love story~. The only real gripe I have against this film is how severely underdeveloped Ethan's character was. He didn't deserve the quotation markable dialogue in the end, because he learned so little even when the lesson was staring right at him.Overall, I loved Joy's story. It separates itself from the usual martyrdom leading ladies in romantic films usually take on.

It's the bothering solitude of my Christmas eve evening that led me to watch this. Kathryn surely deserved that acting award for this film because she single-handedly carried it. Alden too carried for some parts but then again I can't say that much for a character I didn't like. The plot about OFWs hurts because it's honest but the way it's written is loose especially Ethan's backstory. Cannot pity a guy like him. They had a chance na rin naman to showcase Hong Kong as a place na shithole for domestic helpers or a tourist area pero parang di ko naman masyado nakita sa film. Screw the drone shots as well.Also the script, god, the script! I speak in Taglish rin naman but their dialogues are really fictional because if you talk like that in real life then I am actually judging you. Scoring bothered me too because I like the silence of films especially kapag mabigat na yung batuhan. Sorry to the music director but I will not feel anything kapag nilapatan niyo ng overplayed song yan; why can't we just compose new soundtracks for new films? In summary, I give licenses to Kathryn & Alden's fans by presenting this film as proof for their acting calibre then I will snatch it back once they start speaking how good it was.

For a Star Cinema fare, the best thing this film does is to finally not force a happy ending to please its target audience. That was my biggest issue with Cathy-Grace Molina‚Äôs previous film, The Hows of Us ‚Äî resolving all conflicts in order to reach a happy ending that feels fake.Make no mistake, this film is also boggled down by the same trite and cheesy writing (Making Kath‚Äôs and Alden‚Äôs character an official couple is so forced), overblown musical score, and emotionally manipulative sequences that have plagued the quality of Star Cinema films for the past few years.However, this film is effective as a drama that talks about Filipino Diaspora. It even takes away the usually bright gloss aesthetic of a Star Cinema film; which I loved. There‚Äôs a sense of realism at play.It shines at moments when it doesn‚Äôt delve on the romance, but on the struggles faced by Filipinos working abroad. When we are shown how these Filipinos find ways to cope up and form a stronger bond as a community of overseas workers ‚Äî the film is at its most human.Past its flaws, the film is something I appreciated. It‚Äôs a semi-fresh take that is just a bit uneven.
This narrative hits too close to home. I will spend the rest of my 2020 reflecting about my decisions and crying about it. Bye.

**Watched this for class, and we talked about the rift between mainstream and independent cinema in the Philippines.**The opening sequence of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) is almost exactly the same as the first few minutes of Sid & Aya: Not a Love Story (2018), as it makes use of a montage of the scenes to come, all while Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) describes Hong Kong, and her life, and how she perceives love. Again, similarly with Sid & Aya, the first part only follows Joy as she lives her life as a domestic helper, then it pulls the "then it all changed" clich√© when Ethan (Alden Richards) comes in and pulls out some weird and cringe-y pick up lines to woo her (And funny enough, just like Sid & Aya, the woman has little to no interest in the man). This film almost masquerades as the usual mainstream Filipino romance, with its structure and overall production. It has invisible editing, clear visuals, and an upfront and chronological structure (with exception to the first flash forward montage and a few flashbacks). But where Hello, Love, Goodbye diverts from the "usual" is in the complexity of its characters' struggles as its plot progresses. Joy is "lost potential," with the film implying that she was an excellent college graduate. She is almost drowning in responsibilities as a domestic helper, but continues to hustle harder and harder to provide for her family, and to keep her fading dreams alive. Ethan is a hotshot bartender who is secretly full of regret, as he previously left his whole life behind just to chase a girl he desperately loved. Joy and Ethan's dynamic starts out weird, but their love reluctantly grows as Joy comes closer to her dreams and as Ethan slowly comes to terms with his past. Towards the end, as Joy and Ethan are arguing about their future, and what love means to them. Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo's performances are strong and passionate in the later acts (despite some very mushy lines here and there), and perhaps this is where the artistry of the independent film lies. Their performances and their lines are the things I pondered about long after the credits rolled.This film definitely leans more towards the mainstream cinema. The mainstream elements significantly outweigh its "indie" elements. But, it has a certain depth and profoundness in the messages it delivers to its audience thanks to its good writing and performances. It's far from a perfect film, or a film that I would consider a modern classic, but I can definitely see this being enjoyed by a lot of different filmgoers with different tastes, as it does have a little something for everyone. And because of all these, it's clear to see why this is currently the highest grossing film produced in the Philippines.

"The time stops when you don't use it." There's a single aspect in Hello, Love, Goodbye that makes it truly worth watching‚Äîits fairly authentic portrayal of the collective plights of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW). As a former OFW's kid, this one definitely hits home, and it's pretty much the same feeling I had when I watched Sunday Beauty Queen. I have heard a lot of stories about their struggles abroad including from my mom and dad. The moment Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) shouted "I love you all pero 'tangina, pa'no naman ako?" was pretty reminiscent to that of my mom's sentiments about her experience when she was feeling down while at work. It's really sad, and this one spoke so much to me. And so, I'm gonna give this film a point for that. However, other than the things mentioned earlier, everything ranges from being dull to borderline decent. I have to commend Bernardo's very emotional portrayal of a very emotional character. She eventually ended up carrying the entire film, while Alden Richards, despite being constantly labeled among fans and critics for slightly stepping up his game, seemed a little stale. The chemistry was there, but it didn't really hold up in the long run. I also have to acknowledge how problematic the start of their romance was. See it for yourself then. Moreover, the film still succumbs to clich√©d tropes we usually encounter in Filipino romantic films, not to mention the terrible use of music just to evoke emotions that would only work for, dare I say it, wild fans. It's nothing new, so I had to endure it.Hello, Love, Goodbye would have been a huge knockout had it been focusing on Joy's story arc. It's the only thing in the film that I was fully invested in. How it treated the romance aspect was decent at best, but its establishment damaged the film tremendously. Gosh, it could have been so much better, really.

This is the highest-grossing Filipino film ever made, and I literally can't believe it. It‚Äôs impossible. Not because it's a bad movie, but because it's so depressing. It‚Äôd be like if Terms of Endearment were America's.Like on one level it makes some sense: it‚Äôs about two attractive young people who meet and fall in love in an exotic locale, and they‚Äôre played by two huge movie stars. Pretty easy to see how that gets butts in the seat! But....It‚Äôs so bleak. Their lives are so unpleasant. Both are Overseas Filipino Workers stuck in immigration traps in Hong Kong, forced to submit to exploitation in order to retain proper status (one especially tragic scene has a Filipino who's working as a nanny beg her employer to keep her on at half pay because losing the job means getting deported back to the Philippines....and this is a college-educated worker with dreams of being a nurse). Our heroine‚Äôs mother gets beaten by her (foreign) husband whom she despises, but has to stay with him for another few months to become a resident (and then the rest of her family--who were left behind in the Philippines--can join her).The driving force of the movie is essentially how these punitive immigration rules ruin their chance at true love and happiness. It‚Äôs a necessary (and timely) topic, and it‚Äôs handled with great care, but...highest-grossing film ever? Ahead of The Avengers?!?!?

I don't want to be one of those mean letterboxd users, but I just need to write this.---Magiging mas maganda sana ang pelikula na ito, kung tinanggal yung unang parte kung saan "nagpapakipot" si Joy, nangugulit sa text/radyo si Ethan at binibili ang mga paninda niya para magkaroon ng oras sa kanya. Tapos babalik lang din pala ang lahat sa same bar na naging set-up ng istorya. Magiging mas okay pa sana ang character ni Ethan, at ang airtime ng pelikula na ito(!) kung nagkakilala na lang sila sa bar dahil sa trabaho, muntikan na magkaone night stand, at tsaka nagkadevelopan.Mas magiging istorya ito ng dalawang normal na tao, mas magiging natural.Pero hindi, kinailangang gumawa ng "pursue the girl" set-up ang lahat ng romantic films sa Pilipinas. Tama bang 'bilin' ng lalake yung oras niya, para maguilt-trip siya na sumama dito? Also: plot convenience, inispoil ng kapatid ni Ethan (Jameson na halatang di sanay magtagalog) ang buong character background niya sa isang drunken monologue na wala namang nagprovoke. Also: Ethan's friends' trashtalking the girls in the pageant, wtf. Unforgivable.Also: sana wala nalang soundtrack Panghuli: Bakit nag-eenglish bigla mga characters pag iyakan/climactic aminan scene na? (cringe)-- But other than all of that: there is a good film in here--storywise. The heart is there. The women in the film are great! The ending is quite good, too.

A surprisingly affecting romantic drama about the large community of Filipino domestic workers in Hong Kong. This is something that has been recently explored as a more heart warming drama with Oliver Siu Kuen Chan and Anthony Wong's excellent Still Human, however here we have a similar situation but shown almost entirely from the Filipino workers perspective and with a significant romantic plot.Through central character Joy, who wants to be a nurse, but is forced into the domestic helper lifestyle like her mother, it looks at the difficulties and exploitation inherent in these worker's arrangements. Paid a pittance, and treated appallingly by their employers and the state, this film examines how they can be trapped into this existence and life, allowing them to send a bit of money home to family in the Philippines that they only speak to via video calls, promising a reunion that will never happen.There's an excellent movie in here, but the film stumbles significantly when introducing Joy's love interest, barman Ethan. While it may appear like this film is going to be a standard romantic comedy, it's not really, and Ethan's initial characterisation is straight out of a lunatic American rom-com. After being introduced by pretending to be immigration police and arresting Joy, he's harassing and calling her constantly, that even within the constraints of a romantic comedy (which this isn't!), he's basically a stalker.It's a shame that the film goes down this initial cliched route, after introducing Ethan's character for the next twenty minutes, because at it's core, and once Ethan stops behaving like a lunatic, it's a genuinely tender and quite tragic film about a doomed romance, and about how Filipino immigrants to Hong Kong are never made to feel part of society. The films portrayal of both Ethan's father and Joy's parents is well done, and very sympathetic, which makes it more frustrating that they wasted so much time with Ethan's initial character, when they could have skipped that and presented him as he appears for the last hour of the film.It's filmed on the streets and alleys of Hong Kong, and all extremely recognisable and vivid, clearly made by someone who understands the areas, full of classic "oh yeah, I know where they are" moments.Surprisingly bittersweet ending too. This is mostly an excellent film, that's dragged down unnecessarily by the initial appearance of Ethan - made even more frustrating that they roll that characterisation back. Still, definitely worth my time, and a lot better than I expected (but it could have been just that bit better).

5.5/10For me, it‚Äôs a very typical Pinoy romance you‚Äôd expect from Star Cinema, so I won‚Äôt really go into the quality and narrative of the film. What always fascinated me was how this stands as the highest grossing film of all time in the Philippines. Having an OFW-centred story would definitely play a huge role in this benchmark, since the OFW struggle is a very real experience among working class Filipinos. There‚Äôs a whole history behind OFW films that I‚Äôd love to look into further while I‚Äôm still studying Honours.It was also jarring to have watched this after seeing two Wong Kar Wai films these past few days ‚Äî I say this because this film is set in Hong Kong. So for me, it felt like an interesting exercise in comparing both localised and transcultural portrayals of a country. I don‚Äôt really have a right to comment on the way Cathy portrays Hong Kong people, or whether or not this captures an ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù Hong Kong experience outside the OFW life, but this is also something I‚Äôd like to scrutinise more closely.I think I can get behind why people would see this as above average, and despite it being an average experience for me, I appreciate the film for what it is. I would love to write further about the film‚Äôs OFW narrative and transcultural elements, as they are both integral to shaping Philippine cinema as a globalised medium.(PS: watching Kathryn Bernardo sing badly has been the most cathartic thing I‚Äôve seen all year)

Cathy Garcia-Molina departs from rom-coms in a touching tale of sacrifice and love in a city far from home.Leave to pursue your dreams, or stay for the love of your life? This is the question that Hello, Love, Goodbye asks us. This latest offering from Cathy Garcia-Molina, best known for her Filipino romantic comedies, is set in Hong Kong. Molina sheds light on the experiences of Filipinos working overseas by following the story of Joy and Ethan, two Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs). We see their lives unfold through the eyes of Joy, a hardworking domestic helper who‚Äôs trying to save money to move to Canada as a nurse, and Ethan, a bartender trying to find his motivation in life.Hello, Love, Goodbye stars two of the Philippines‚Äô biggest names from the two of the biggest ‚Äúloveteams‚Äù‚ÄîKathryn Bernardo (from KathNiel) and Alden Richards (from AlDub). What‚Äôs also surprising is that Bernado and Richards are from rival television networks; in the Philippines, it‚Äôs common for actors to be signed to one network exclusively. Their performance in Hello, Love, Goodbye proves that once in a while, it doesn‚Äôt hurt to break out of your loveteam to grow as an artist. An Empathetic, Authentic PerformanceIn Hello Love, Goodbye, Bernado graduates from her teen roles and blossoms into a dramatic actress‚Äîa total transformation from her child acting days‚Äîin a tour de force performance. Richards rises to the challenge and exhibits his versatility as an actor, proving why he‚Äôs one of the country‚Äôs matinee idols.To get into their roles, Bernardo was separated from the cast to better empathize with Joy‚Äôs feelings of isolation; after just a week of filming in Hong Kong, she wanted to go back to the Philippines. Richards, on the other hand, lost almost 25 kg to play Ethan. Molina is notorious for her strictness with the artists that she works with‚Äîbut it‚Äôs paid off as they are all household names, and her films have been blockbuster hits.Hello, Love, Goodbye‚Äôs love story is not new, yet it provides us with a unique perspective of the realities of being an overseas worker. The film tears away the layers of the OFW experience with sheer intensity. Shifting away from showing the employee-employer relationship found in other films about OFWs, Molina brings her focus to the OFWs themselves, and their families back home.The film strips down the glamor of Hong Kong, as we follow Joy waking up at 5am every day, hustling through the crowded streets of Hong Kong‚Äîaway from her family, never catching a dream. She sits down on top of cardboard boxes on Sundays in Central and juggles taking care of her employer‚Äôs daughter and grandmother while selling power banks as a side job (which is actually illegal). Molina blends drama and clarity in portraying these hardships, and most importantly, tells the ‚Äúwhys.‚ÄùThe Burden of Responsibility‚ÄúIf you stop, you‚Äôll starve‚Äù‚Äîthat‚Äôs the reason why.Joy, and thousands of other OFWs, endure these hardships to provide for their family back home‚Äîa message that the film strongly reinforces. We watch as Joy‚Äôs friend reminds her cousin to be smart with her money so she can have enough to send back to the Philippines, as the same friend tells her father that she‚Äôll stay two more years because they need the money.Domestic helpers only earn as little as HK$4,520 (US$576) per month, while working long hours. In Joy‚Äôs words, if you stop working, your family will starve. Making sacrifices is almost always a given‚Äîa harsh reality if you‚Äôre an OFW because you have a responsibility to your family back home. This responsibility that Joy carries is one that resonates with many other OFWs.But OFWs carry out this responsibility at what expense?Similar to Still Human, which also featured a Filipino domestic helper, Joy has a degree in nursing. In fact, nursing is a common degree among Filipinos with the hope of working overseas for better pay than what they can get back home. As it turns out, nursing is actually the dream that Joy wants to pursue, and being a domestic helper is just a stepping stone to that goal.Then Ethan comes into the picture. While a movie following the plight of domestic helpers and OFWs doesn‚Äôt really need a romance story, the love story still has a purpose. Ethan‚Äôs character contrasts with Joy‚Äôs. While Joy is hardworking, determined, and knows what she wants in life, Ethan is a happy-go-lucky guy who jumps from one relationship to the next and doesn‚Äôt know what he wants in life. But his character‚Äôs free-wheeling life also echoes Joy‚Äôs self-questioning of whether choosing ourselves over our family makes us a disappointment, or selfish.Joy laments the lack of choice she has in life. As the family‚Äôs breadwinner, her family doesn‚Äôt know what she has to endure on a daily basis. A nursing graduate that cleans the toilet and eats leftover food‚Äî‚ÄúI‚Äôm more than this job, I‚Äôm more, and I want to be more,‚Äù Joy says.Surely, this sentiment reflects the many dreams of other overseas Filipino workers. They have dreams but they also have responsibilities that hold them back. Joy and Ethan‚Äôs romance show the heavy burdens and choices OFWs face on a daily basis. Even something as minor as buying a snack or not is difficult, because every dollar spent is a dollar you could have saved to give back to your family.Dreams vs. LoveA common Filipino phrase, ‚Äúlibre lang mangarap,‚Äù tells us ‚Äúit‚Äôs free to dream‚Äù. But Joy and Ethan realize, as they try to make their love work, that dreams aren‚Äôt free. When you make a choice, you give up something.Joy and Ethan‚Äôs mutual romance story mirrors the same sentiments that their individual stories have: choices, responsibilities, and dreams. Perhaps that‚Äôs the reason why the romance element works against the backdrop of an OFW story. In this sense, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn‚Äôt just a love story, nor is it just an OFW story‚Äîit‚Äôs a story about finding yourself, and loving yourself in the process. This universal message is something that will strike a chord with audiences.Hello, Love, Goodbye‚Äòs message is simple: give yourself the chance to do what you want, get back up from disappointments, be courageous enough to love and choose whether you want to leave or stay. The film doesn‚Äôt portray Bernardo and Alden as people to pity‚Äîit portrays them as human beings, with stories and experiences that empower them to ultimately choose how to pave their own way for their futures‚Äîwith or without each other.

Even then, I felt most of the time we were being kept at arms‚Äô length from the characters; close, intimate shots were so rarely used. I like its very mature approach to relationships, though, and by echoing the ending of the sparer, more eloquent Endo, it illuminated the ending of that movie for me, showing that by not pursuing his love before she‚Äôs ready, the guy is showing commitment and hope, a willingness to wait. It showed his character had grown, also it‚Äôs something anyone who wants to get somewhere in life needs these days, so it‚Äôs good that Filipino films are promoting this value!

Finally, I watched the highest grossing Filipino movie of all time as well! Hello, Love, Goodbye was on my list since it‚Äôs official release. With the new pairing I took some time to get into the mood. All my Filipino friends confirmed to me that the portrayal OFWs is indeed a very accurate one. It was indeed frustrating to watch the everyday struggle and hard work of educated young people in minor jobs to support their family. Nowadays it belongs to the normality to support their families through migration. It‚Äôs indeed a very depressing atmosphere and all the problems and concerns were well portrayed by Katheryn Bernardo in this movie. She did an amazing job as usual. But this time the melodramatic vibe really flashed me. Same for Alden Richards. I have to admit that I had my doubts to see Katheryn in a movie without Daniel but all my concerns were for nothing. The whole superstar casting and the successful capture of the OFWs situation makes this movie captivating. I really enjoyed the realistic view and the reality that hits the viewer in every scene. The survival and emotional struggle is detailed pictured and I really loved it that the characters stay true to themselves, no matter how hard is life.To be honest, the depressing reality clash were indeed very much needed and an eye opener for a foreign audience. The movie promises nothing and stays true to itself like it‚Äôs main protagonists.

I love how Philippine mainstream cinema (like the highest grossing films) is dominated by WOMEN and LGBT+ (AS IT SHOULD!), unlike Hollywood which mostly caters to film bros LOL. *But also the irony that we have the most misogynistic, sexist, homophobic piece of shit as Pres üíÄ* The way many people here support movies that film bros might deem too feminine, I love that for us. Like if you go out on the streets and ask an ordinary Pinoy any director they know, high chance that you‚Äôll hear Cathy Garcia-Molina, Joyce Bernal, Antoinette Jadaone, which is the exact opposite in the international scene where names like Lav Diaz (deserved tho), Brillante Mendoza, or Erik Matti are more recognized (well Isabel Sandoval too but just referring to the ones based in PH).Well, at least female directors are popular amongst the locals haha (unlike in other countries where the local and international scene are still heavily dominated by male directors). Sorry talaga, direk Cathy kasi I first watched this on my laptop thru a Google Drive link. Now I saw this on TV. Ganda pa rin. Kathryn Bernardo has really improved, her performance here aged well. You can feel her heartache, longing, and regret through her eyes and body language. She really did well in portraying the struggle of our Filipina DHs.Hong Kong, so close yet so far. It's a colonial outpost that serves as a microcosm of global labor relations: tired, underpaid, overworked, yet cheerful, patient Third World women on its busy shopping streets facing their haughty, cruel, and privileged Cantonese bosses who pride themselves in their neocolonial, Anglo-Saxon upbringing. The story is really familiar to me. I saw how many women in my family worked abroad (and some in HK) and faced such hardships to provide for their own families here. I hate how Filipinos are conditioned and trained to be machines for labor export. I hope the Philippine Revolution finally succeeds soon.

Film # 833 of the 13% challengeDirector Cathy Garcia-MolinaWhat a nice surprise to find out the highest grossing Phillipine film of all time was directed by a woman. This was at its best whenever Joy was onscreen as she was perfectly played by Kathryn Bernardo and her character was well developed and interesting. On the downside, the love story and the various subplots served no purpose and detracted from the overall enjoyment with the final act falling into full-on maudlin, soap opera territory.

This is one of the best films of Modern FIlipino cinema I would say especially in the field of mainstream media. It's no surprise that the film is the highest grossing in the Philippines. I like how Joy's character and how she narrates the film through her eyes. I like how she's not ashamed to tell her job to one of her friends. I like how she's so candid in trying to keep herself whole amidst the things that try to crumble her into broken pieces. I like how she well portrays how awful and difficult it is for people like her to be steps closer in attaining her goals. This is one of Kath's best roles to date. I also like how Ethan made it a bit difficult for her to leave Hong Kong after falling into each other's intentions and vulnerabilities. What's a bit problematic though is Ethan's character especially in the beginning. It could be a little offsetting if it were to be done to girls in real life with him being a bit pushy when a girl you like is already gate keeping herself from you. But it's good that there was some character development from him going halfway through the film. It's nice he understand Joy has big plans to fulfill and he trusts they'll be together in time.Love is really the most complicated thing. It makes you question if your own dreams are really worth giving up if you can have another one with the person you love. It makes you question what road God has paved to you. But in the end you'll realize that your destiny is what your freewill desires anyway. If dreams are worth fighting for, love can find a way to be a part of it in the end.

"Isn't that how its supposed to be? When you love, all or nothing. If you hold back, then why love at all?"Hello, Love, Goodbye is my first Filipino film! I've been looking forward to this one for a while. I gotta say though, I think I prefer Wong Kar Wai's portrayal of Hong Kong to Cathy Garcia-Molina's. Hello, Love, Goodbye tells a very standard love story that's been done numerous times before, and better. A couple meets for a short amount of time in a foreign country, and then are parted by time. This film is incredibly soap-opera esque, and there are a lot of scenes with heavy over-acting and some delicious scenery chewing. The audio mixing is also all over the place. The actors can usually be heard fine, but sometimes the music drowns out what they are saying during important scenes. Some of the dialogue is also really unintentionally hilarious, like the scene where a character is berated for opening a bar instead of becoming a doctor or store manager. No offense to anyone out there, but I would probably be more impressed with someone who opened their own restaurant than someone who manages a Walgreens üòÇThe pacing is also all over the place, and the film is way too long for what its trying to accomplish. There are some genuinely sweet moments hidden amidst the saccharine sea that is Hello, Love, Goodbye, but I couldn't help but feel that this movie is frighteningly similar to those "inspirational/romantic" YouTube videos that get roasted from time to time.If you're looking for a light, modern-pop romance film, you could do a lot worse than Hello, Love, Goodbye. It's silly, but sincere. I personally struggled to care about this movie strongly, but I promise there are some really nice moments scattered throughout. I think there is a really good movie buried in here, but it'll take some work to unearth it.

There‚Äôs a constant struggle among love, family, and dreams. As Filipinos, we already grew up taking this huge responsibility to give back to our parents once we land a stable job and earn something to sustain ourselves and the needs of our family. We need to adhere to this concern because the breadwinners were sometimes deprived to live their dreams because of the unexpected weight of responsibility we carry once we earn a degree.In addition, there‚Äôs a heavy feeling after watching this film. It took a while for me to process things and calm myself from crying. A good mix of Kathryn and Alden. Their tandem is an interesting one.

March Around The World 2022 (7/30)I, for some reason, thought this was a bog standard cheesy rom-com, and I put it on my potential watch list for this challenge because I knew I had some others with kind of heavy subject matter and wanted a few lighter options in the mix too. Cut to 20 minutes from the end and I am sobbing, SOBBING! Not what I was expecting at all. I'll be honest, Ethan's initial pursuit of Joy is maybe questionable, and judging by the most popular review for this film, a lot of people could not see past that, which is a shame, I think. Once the characters actually connect properly this is a really sweet and lovely romance. And as much time as that romance does take up, it's not at the expense of Joy as a character. She is always at the centre of this story, which is about so much more than a really quite cute love story. I wasn't familiar at all with the cultural setting here, but I think there's enough context for everything that it's very easy to understand the employment situations, as well as the family commitments, and all the stress and pressure that comes with that. Joy and Ethan's situations are different but they're a result of the same social, economic and familial restrictions/obligations, and these things hang over their romance the whole time, which adds a layer of urgency and also sadness to them both. There's a scene pretty early on with Joy on a bus, and she bumps into an old college friend, there on his honeymoon, and it's just devastating. I knew at that point this wasn't the film I was expecting it to be. Kathryn Bernardo is quietly heartbreaking in that scene, and she really does centre this entire film. And later when she realises that she's been working towards an unattainable goal for her family, and now she finally gets to have a choice of what happens to her but it's not as simple as she hoped it might be, I was so invested in her that my heart was simultaneously soaring for her, while also breaking. There's one or two little things in here that keep it from being 5 stars, but if you can see past Ethan's somewhat questionable initial pursuit of Joy then there's a really beautiful film here.

The highest grossing Filipino film of all time (not counting inflation).It‚Äôs pretty bland, uninspired, and very cliche-driven film. There‚Äôs not really a lot to say about it. The most interesting aspect of this otherwise heinous picture is its idealized portrait of OFW life, which opens questions that are not only timely, but important discussions that need to be had about the Philippine economy and its foreign relations.The love story is also forgettable. I didn‚Äôt feel a single shred of compatibility between Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo, despite Bernardo being a memorable actress. The love story can effectively be removed and it would be a better whole. I‚Äôve just seen too much of these horrendous love formulas spanning the pre-war era to be moved by a stale production.
