A good romance/drama set in Hong Kong where the main character is working as a domestic helper to help her family back home in the Philippines. As the months get closer to her moving for new opportunities in Canada, she meets a bartender also from the Philippines and as they get closer, has to decide whether to stay or go.While the romantic drama was a little too much for me in some parts, it was awesome to see a movie centered around characters representing the overseas population from the Philippines, who probably make up the largest foreign population in Hong Kong.I loved the non-cliche ending and the characters were likable. It is also the current highest-grossing film from the Philippines of all time, which is pretty awesome!

I think ito na ang extent ng pagiging experimental ng Star Cinema, lol.First and foremost, Kathryn Bernardo proved once again that she can evoke whatever emotion she wants from her audience. She acts with her eyes, body language, speech tone, just overflowing with passion! Nakakadala ang performance niya!I don't quite get why every single major family in the film had a member who had some sory of disability. It didn't really contribute anything to the story's development nor was it even explored through dialogue. It felt like an easy excuse to elicit sympathy from the viewers, which is problematic as PWDs have been forever subject to being accessorized in films and tv.Wasn't a fan of Alden's character. Too shallow imo. However, Alden himself did a great job in matching Kathryn's splendid acting! He was decent enough to keep me engaged.Played it safe on the ending. Of course, it had to have even a tinge of a happy ending because it is a mainstream film and lots of Filipinos consider a film bad if it doesn't have a light or a positive-leaning ending. It was building up nicely to an emotional climax but the moment Joy and Ethan had that confrontation scene, everything that followed felt like an attempt to repair the sad atmosphere that it produced. I wish the film maximized that misery and took a full-on drama end. Maybe then it would have more impact.Technicalities were subpar. The film did not look aesthetically pleasing most of the time. Perhaps it wanted to portray the gritty experience of living as a DH in HK, but it could have been better. Score utterly sucked. The audience does not need to hear a full track while the scenes transpire. This is not a music video.Tolerable, for sure. Kathryn carried it.

"The time stops when you don't use it."A heartfelt romantic comedy drama set in Hong Kong following the story of Joy and Ethan, two filipino immigrants. Its not a new story, but it blends the hardships, sacrifice, dreams, love & realities of a overseas domestic worker quite empathetically. The pairing of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards was so charming & sweet.Hello, Love, Goodbye‚Äòs message is simple: give yourself the chance to do what you want, get back up from disappointments, be courageous enough to love and choose whether you want to leave or stay. The film doesn‚Äôt portray Bernardo and Alden as some people who need your pity‚Äîbut rather portrays the characters humanely, with stories and experiences that empower them to ultimately choose how to pave their own way for their futures‚Äîwith or without each other. A warm satisfying drama.(ending made me ugly cry lol)Alden Richards<333333333333

This film emanates comfort, uncertainty, and self-worth. And that is what Philippine cinema should put out not hundreds of generic cringy-ass rom-com films. Joy, a struggling Filipino DH, who has specific dreams for herself and her family meets Ethan who doesn't exactly know what he wants. A literal manifestation of the 'Grumpy x Sunshine' trope, and I'm here for it. Joy finds comfort in Ethan, even if she isn't exactly looking for a relationship.Amid their emerging relationship, Ethan finds himself filled with uncertainty as his time with Joy comes close to its end. He deeply hopes that Joy will change her mind as he planned everything out for their future. But this is where it gets tricky, Joy has already made up her mind, from the start. She knows what she wants, even Ethan can't change her mind. And I support and understand her. All her life, she has put her family first, and this time she needs to prioritize herself. Ethan does not deserve Joy's half-self if she even chooses to stay, cause she will always have 'what ifs' and that would also be unfair for Ethan.In simple terms, Joy needs to find herself. To feel that she is her own person. Only then will she be able to give herself committedly to Ethan, and he understood that in the end.This is when two persons respect each other's dreams and are both willing to let go of each other to grow individually and come back when they're both ready.Alden & Kath > Kathniel, I still stand by this.

a kathryn bernardo stan through and throughnot the first time i've seen this so i always knew ethan's character is so problematic, but i guess that's a point to be made so the development can have more depth. a guy who's immature and foolish and always putting his heart above all else, learning that letting go is another form of loving when all he'd ever known is to go for what he can reach if it makes him happy, and a girl that lived her life so small and consuming due to the sacrifices needed to be made at every corner, finding the kind of love that presented her the choice that could be the turning point of everything. in ethan, she found the strength to choose herself. in joy, he found a love that encourages him to be more.it was questionable and doomed from the start, but if i know anything about love, it's that enough of it can really be the euphoria you need in your darkest, heaviest days. at the end, finding each other made them better. and with just that, none of the love was lost.

#stoprussiai used to avoid this movie like the plague out of fear that i might get the unnecessary and unsolicited feels, but after several years i am happy to report that i was only able to see the movie for what it was and did not (un)intentionally project my personal experiences into what the film portrayedi could say that my goals are much more defined now, and what i want out of a deeper connection from a person is clearer, one that gives me a certain sense of agency; not marred by deception, mindfuckery, or misguided intentions; nor should it amplify my weaknesses more than my (unfounded) potentialchoosy na kung choosy ;)

Dari judulnya kupikir film ini tentang cinta-cintaan klise dengan latar luar negeri. IH TAPI TERNYATA... Ketampar abis. Heeeeiiii film ini ternyata bagussss. Seenggaknya menurutku.Kathryn Bernardo di sini bener-bener mirip Ayu Ting-Ting. Eh, nggak. Yang bener Kathryn Bernardo di sini bener-bener berpenampilan cewek biasa-biasa aja, yang masuk ke karakternya. Di sini dia berperan jadi Joy, lulusan S1 yang kesulitan dapat kerja. Dia ngerantau ke Hongkong, berpikiran mau kerja apa aja yang penting dapat uang. Karena mau hijrah ke Kanada jadi perawat dan ngeboyong keluarganya hidup sejahtera di sana. Dia nggak ada waktu buat senang-senang, termasuk buat cinta-cintaan. Kerja kerja kerja mulu. Sampai akhirnya ada cowok datang ke dalam hidupnya, pengen deketin dia tapi dia nggak mau nggak mau nggak mau. Nggak bermaksud jual mahal, tapi dia memang nggak punya waktu buat pacaran.Aku suka film ini. Aku tau rasanya jadi Joy, terutama pas dia yang kerja sama orang Hongkong. Aku pernah kerja sama orang Chinese dan keras sih dunia kerjanya. Simple-nya mereka ngomong kayak marah-marah padahal sebenarnya ngomong biasa aja. Ketika ngelakuin kesalahan kecil, mereka bisa marahnya gedeeeeee banget. Aku nggak bermaksud rasis lho ini ya.Interaksinya Joy dan si cowok di mana si cowok nggak gentar deketin. Disuruh pergi ajaaaa nggak pengen pacaran ya bebal tetap aja dekat, ngingatin aku sama ayangku. Dulu dia juga gitu ke aku, ketika aku malasssss banget buat pacaran karena nggak mau sakit hati lagi buang-buang waktu bikin aku selama ini nggak produktif, dia tetap aja maju.Aku mau fokus kerja aja, karena ketika aku galau karena pacar ya bisa ambyar kerjaanku. Singkatnya ini film tentang orang miskin itu nggak bisa milih. Nggak punya pilihan. Termasuk mau pilih wujudin cita-cita atau cinta. Sediiiiiiih. Orang miskin nggak bisa 'egois' üò≠

Ang dami kong nabasa at narinig na rave reviews ng pelikula na ito kaya na delay ang panonood ko. And that was one of the worst decision I made. I think I found my most favorite Cathy Garcia Molina movie. This is her best work. And Kathryn, wow! I think I found a new respect to you as an actor.Some of my favorites:1. Cinematography - grabe ang ganda ng pag capture sa Hong Kong and how it tells the story of our domestic helpers2. The setting helped in the storytelling, hindi lang siya background. 3. JOY AND HER CHOICE AS A WOMAN - galit talaga ako sa mga babaeng character sa pelikula ni CGM but Joy gave me so much joy. How she insisted that she needs to decide for herself and her happiness. This is cinema! Chos. Add the scene where the character of Cacai asked the question about women being selfish when she choose herself!Mga not so favorite:- Fat jokes! Talaga ba?- The neverending family struggle. I guess it will not be a star cinema movie if there's no conflict with the family. Kaya nga hindi na resolve na domestic abuse victim ang nanay ni Joy. Because there's too many family drama!!! - Medyo makulit si Ethan when he courted JoyOverall, this was really a great movie. Please Kathryn, continue making this kind of movie and choosing this type of character. You have a new fan in me.

A story in two layers. The first is with Joy and her experiences as a Filipino overseas domestic helper living in Hong Kong. We not only delve into her journey of wanting a better life for her and her family, but we also get a glimpse of this particular subculture of Filipinos living in Hong Kong, who have carved out a little community for themselves away from their home. Between poor pay, long hours of work, and shuffling through countless jobs and hustles to make ends meet, seeing these workers come together to host their own makeshift beauty pageant, or weeping together as they're watching Filipino dramas on someone's phone while they're in the middle of illegally peddling retail, it's those small moments of solidarity that adds a charming touch. It adds an extra dimension to this life that isn't just all doom, gloom, and abuse (and sadly there's a lot of it) to make you sympathize with their struggle.The second layer is a Wattpad fueled, Twilight charged romance full of the same toxic tropes with the weird stalking and complete disregard for boundaries. They made sure to make Ethan seem like such a bad boy who can get any woman he wants (and they display this by his friends joking around about how all his flings are named after a day in the week), yet he drops them all for Joy because...I don't know actually. Maybe it's at this crucible where a bachelor--who has no reason to like a woman who doesn't come from money--suddenly becoming obsessed with her that people find truly romantic, but then he admits to later gaslighting and manipulating her the entire time towards the end (but he did it for love!).That cute montage of them taking selfies all over iconic landmarks in Hong Kong while a Filipino ballad lulls in the background, is supposed to ignite lots of warm feelings in the belly, but for those who didn't buy into this relationship, can feel misplaced. The only part of the romance I liked were Joy and Ethan's friends cheering their relationship on. Others may see them as one dimensional who act as nothing but cheerleaders, but these Filipino romances know how to make really damn great cheerleading supporting characters that makes you wish you had them in your life. Now if only these male leads can actually be decent guys for once.

There's something deeply depressing about stumbling across a boy you loved in the past inside a crowded train, who's there with his pregnant wife. And having to tell him "I ended up like my mother after all."This movie started out so strong, but as it began to focus on their love story I just couldn't bring myself to be invested in it. The male lead was honestly immature and did not carry as much depth as the female MC. And I kept wanting to explore more of her history and depth. I honestly wish the movie was longer, enough that we could see her family, friends and their stories more. They clearly have their own stories that are reminiscent of all the Non-chinese hongkongers who sacrifice everything to suffer in a foreign nation for money. The opening montage is so good and reminded of Kimi No Nawa's.And I loved that I could trace the geography of my country in this movie. Either way, this movie was so so good.

Let's continue the anti-love theme formula.Ang ganda. Sa trend ng movies na lumalabas ngayon, its one of the decent ones. Una, kase nag-work yung Alden-Kathryn team up. Pangalawa, kahit napapansin kong most Filipino romcoms ay may storyline na nagaganap sa ibang bansa, napansin kong never pumunta sa ibang lugar yung mga characters. Like yung buong film, sa Hong Kong. Mapwera lang dun sa scenes sa bahay nila Kathryn which is sobrang minimal. Third, naramdaman ko. Mas madaling hanapan ng simpatya yung mga characters ni Joy at Ethan. Mga nagsusumikap para sa pamilya, mga nagpupursiging matupad pangarap nila, mga nagmamahal pero may tamang limitations. Like sobrang ganda ng growth ni Ethan. Sobrang earned.

In all honesty, this could have been better if the film focused more on the struggles and reality of becoming a domestic helper in HongKong rather than the romance of the two characters. Ethan, the male lead, was so infuriating at times during the movie. He only had his redemption arc at the last 14 minutes of the movie. Joy, on the other hand, literally carried this movie. Her acting was really great and I could really feel her emotions during the scenes. As I said before, this would be better without the romance. I couldn‚Äôt root for the guy because he border-lined harassed the girl and manipulated/gaslighted her for choosing herself this time. Not to mention the cheesy liners that was out of place since it looked like he was invalidating her problems. I am genuinely happy with the ending and I am glad that this became a hit in the Philippines because I am tired of the culture that romanticizes struggles as long as you are together.

ang choice para sa mayayaman. Hello, Love, Goodbye perfectly portrayed the stories of OFWs in Hong Kong. Working as an OFW wasn't a choice. They had to, at the cost of their dreams. At the cost of what they could have been. Cheating. Marriage of convenience. Leaving your family behind. These have now become a norm in the OFW culture and society when it shouldn't be. It's a bitter reality of what you would do for your loved ones just to bring them up a level higher on the economic ladder. Being selfish is okay. Choosing to chase for your dreams and to find yourself is okay. Because love alone cannot solely support two people. Can love feed you when you're broke? NO. How could you add one more person in your life when you can barely take care of yourself, right?Anyway, highest respect for all the Joy Marie Fabregas out there. I aspire to be as strong as her.

Joy is my bias from kathryn's characters. Grabe yung impact niya, yung deep ng character niya. Ang galing ni Kathryn, you can really feel how tired and drained she is. I'm really glad na hindi siya nag stay and she chose to chase her dream and prioritize her self this time. thank u joy, you taught me to be more <3

Hello, Love, Goodbye revolves around the lives of Joy and Ethan; both are Filipino workers based in Hong Kong. Joy is a domestic helper who dreams of working as a nurse in Canada while Ethan is a bartender who is waiting out his permanent residency. Just like how most romantic films go, these two characters meet, fall in love, then‚Ä¶ life happens.Hello, Love, Goodbye not just a love story, it‚Äôs a life story. About making a choice between love and chasing after your dream. Joy, as the breadwinner, works hard to give herself and her family a better life. She also actively engages in her buy-and-sell business every sunday, and even takes on a second job at night as a waitress. She desperately needs funds not only to send back home, but also to finance her dream of flying off to Canada to practice nursing, her original course. Ethan, on the other hand, is on the road to redemption after letting down his own family. He was supposed to have gained Hong Kong residency already but he left and went to the US to pursue a girl he loved. They broke up and he had to go back to zero in Hong Kong. One is burdened by her family while also committed to her dreams, the other tethered to the idea of making amends to the people closest to him, and a relationship is the last thing they need in their lives.Point of the story was about making choices, no matter how difficult they may be. Joy said ‚Äúchoice is only for the rich.‚Äù And she is partly correct. Choice is a luxury only the privileged can afford. It is true that not all of us can have a fair opportunity in life, that‚Äôs why when we had a chance we should make sure to grab it and used it. Joy, in the end, realized that she also has to think of herself first and made her own choices for herself, even if it means that she can‚Äôt be with Ethan. And it‚Äôs not selfish to choose your priorities first, since no one can fully understand your decisions even they say so. Choosing yourself is not an act of ‚Äúselfishness‚Äù. No matter how many reasons you may have to stay and give up on your dreams‚Äîeven if these include people you love the most‚Äîin the end, choosing yourself is still the most fulfilling decision you can do. Of course, if I am in the position of Ethan, I will also do everything for Joy to stay, but we can‚Äôt control everything. Sometimes loving someone also means giving them wings to explore horizons of growth.

A romance different enough from the formula to make it interesting yet close enough to keep it undeniably familiar.The first third of the film was filled with much promise, dipping its toes on social commentary by exploring the world of Filipino domestic helpers in Hong Kong. In the film‚Äôs first conflict, we see Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) deftly running away from police ‚Äî even hiding in the garbage. This must not be her first time.Was this film going to have something to say about the Filipino diaspora?Once it begins to introduce the romance, though, it left that promise to immerse deeply in the tried-and-tested formula. Which is not such a bad thing.What‚Äôs refreshing about it is its confident departure from two-dimensional, well-defined fantasy. An attempt to re-define the ‚ÄòStar Cinema romantic film‚Äô, as it were. I once read about the ‚ÄòStar Cinema audience‚Äô ‚Äôs rigid expectation of their movies, that they enter the theater fully expecting their ‚Äòhappily-ever-after‚Äôs and their convenient closures.* While I disagree with this sense of non-adventure, it is na√Øve to discount this insight significant enough to define the film-watching market for generations. Garcia-Molina‚Äôs cache is exactly in catering to this sensibility.The scene of Ethan‚Äôs (Alden Richards) introduction is as jarring to Joy as Ethan‚Äôs character is to the film. To be honest, I kept on expecting him to revert to some sort of savior trope in Joy‚Äôs life all throughout the film, even in his turn as a toxic Nice Guy in a pivotal moment further in the story. To her credit, Garcia-Molina gave Ethan the room to decide realistically and bear the weight of these choices‚Äò consequences.It was surprising how natural Richards was able to play Ethan. The writers forced his character to say some purely cheesy lines for the sake of saying them ‚Äî as lip service to this Twitter generation ‚Äî but Richards was somehow able to pull it off. And Bernardo did well enough in her turn as the headstrong Joy that I merely had to stop comparing her to Nadine Lustre and start appreciating what she was giving to the film.The chemistry was there, too, in that I could see them pulling off a dialogue-heavy romance √† la THAT THING CALLED TADHANA, which is in no way easy to do. Those scenes where they were wasting time beside each other were gold.If our mainstream romance is really shaping up to this mold ‚Äî influenced by the efforts of Antoinette Jadaone, Dan Villegas, Sigrid Bernardo, and others from the independent scene ‚Äî then I‚Äôm definitely looking forward to more pleasantly-surprising, insightful entertainment.‚Äî*Don Jaucian, ‚ÄúHow Black Sheep is trying to ‚Äòdisrupt‚Äô Philippine cinema,‚Äù https://www.cnnphilippines.com/life/entertainment/Film/2019/6/4/black-sheep-films-interview.html

i am sick, i have a cough, it's 3 am, and i mostly screamed at the top of my lungs ONLY during the first half of this movie. only the first half. no more than the first half. and i still half-regret those pillow-screams because i think my cough is a lot worse than it was roughly 117 minutes ago. being ph's highest-grossing movie ever, i've given myself the expectations of this being quite the questionable, predictable, formulaic, cheesy, on-the-nose, and all the more problematic typical romantic flick that this was reviewed to be, and ended up being. and yet, the crazy thing was they really got me in the first half, and i got what they were giving me (some screams, some pillow punching, some inevitable cringing on corny lines but i was smiling the whole time), so that's at least a mission success.

Kathryn‚Äôs talent is way beyond her years but she can‚Äôt just carry the entire film on her own.Still don‚Äôt understand how mainstream Filipino films have a common fetish of basing an entire film abroad without illuminating its sociopolitical and cultural nuances. Can plots please have another personality besides relishing in xenocentrism? Our country has so much to offer, not to say that filming abroad is outright worthy of condemnation. At least work hard and present matters about that country that people already know off the top of their heads.It has the sincerity of people in a photo-booth posing against a green screen. Sayang. I enjoyed how they showed the plight of domestic helpers in Hong Kong, but the machismo of Alden‚Äôs character and the dry jokes rendered it an unenjoyable watch.Women shouldn‚Äôt have to sacrifice their progress for a man, any man, whether it be her father, a billionaire, or a misogynist deadbeat who professes his undying love for her.The score was incredibly tacky.We need more films about the Filipino diaspora.

I appreciate the premise and how it's been told. The realities of being an OFW and how specific it is in the context of the Filipino community in Hong Kong.What bothered me were two things:1. Is a preference thing, but Alden and Kathryn held their own, but apparently doesn't work together for me? Chemistry is lackluster, I hate to admit it but I don't feel for them as a couple here. And it is a romance so it's kind of fundamental.2. Is a technical thing - But I was bothered how this was filmed all throughout in 16:9 ratio. I feel like it diminished the scenic appreciation for the location which is Hong Kong. It could be beautifully picturesque in a theater screen, but with the ratio it felt very TV show. This is basically me nitpicking but I would appreciate a noticeable difference with TV and movie.But overall, not a bad watch. Did it waste my time? Not really. Will I consciously choose to watch this again? To kill time, maybe. Does it deserve to be the highest grossing Filipino film? Debatable. The cast was heavily influencing for that.

There have been a number of films about the life of an overseas Filipino worker, as our country is unique to have a very significant population pursuing this route. Among these films, there are gems that stood the test of time, and probably influenced real life and further films, as we see in a scene in this film.What makes Hello, Love, Goodbye enjoyable is how effortless it presents the culture, the active and passive decisions, that OFWs take, to fulfill their purpose. While there is a wide cast of characters with their corresponding side stories, nothing feels misplaced. Maybe a few were quite less filling, the different facets and permutation of circumstances of Filipinos living abroad, provides a peek to a rich tapestry for wider stories of these characters.More than how these stories are told, as enhanced by the shot choices and camera movement that let you fall in love with the cityscapes, is the courage to not shy away from the route of the socially desired, mainstream choice.Until when though do Filipinos need to be pressured to make these choices, to enter these circumstances?

God, when will the Philippines retire the overly persistent dude wearing down the uninterested girl with his charms? This film kind of makes up for it with the sheer support radiating off both the characters later in the movie, but it, along with other well-worn cliches, threaten to wear the movie down. Thankfully, though, it doesn't. It's still very much typical Pinoy romcom, but it's also one of the best examples of the genre. There is poignancy, clear-set goals from each character, and most of all, a lack of certainty in the end of their love story. Most other films bend over backwards to provide easy answers, but this movie doesn't. Joy's young cousin doesn't overcome the hardships she faces as a newly-minted domestic helper, but she does tap out and get out of them. Joy and Ethan come together at a time in Joy's life when she is just about to leave to Canada in search of greener pastures. Discontentment and resentment fester in each of the lead's personal lives in ways that don't always go away so easily. And yet...not all solutions come clean. Hello, Love, Goodbye gets that. It as a movie has experienced true life, and despite being cornier than most, it's got its finger on the pulse of the way people love and laugh, especially when time is so fleeting. This is the best acting work on either of the two sides, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards. A change of pace brings out the best in you, I think.

Hello, Love, Goodbye owes its strength in how well-written Joy's character is. She braved leaving the Philippines for Hong Kong to be able to provide for her family and fulfill her dream of uniting her family again. She had to sacrifice a lot of things to be able to make it a reality, yet she remained steadfast in what she wanted did even if she had to give up on love.Here, we see Kathryn at her best. And it's nice to see her paired with Alden who's able to keep up with her. Other aspects of the movie needed improvement, but Kathryn's acting prowess carried the movie through.

i‚Äôve been putting off watching this movie for years now because when it first came out, several of my friends mentioned that joy reminded them of me.and then i noticed that netflix is removing this title tomorrow so i thought why not?hello, love, goodbye is yet another ode to our country‚Äôs unsung heroes‚Äîour overseas workers, but with a more authentic touch. it takes on new angles and anchors its narrative specifically to hong kong, which coincidentally happens to be one of my favorite places and the only country im inclined to visit more than once in my lifetime. maybe im biased.this film reminded me of my yayas my family helped to get to hong kong to seek greener pastures and my own relatives who took a gambit and flew out of the philippines to get a better shot at life as well. it spoke to me as a fellow ate / eldest sister who‚Äôd do anything for my family, even if it meant doing so at my own expense.hello, love, goodbye is an honest portrait of our culture and a reminder that we filipinos have a shared existence that transcends time and place‚Äîfind comfort in that.other notes:‚Äúminsan gusto ko na lang maging selfish at iwanan lahat ng responsibilidad ko. nagagalit ako kasi parang wala akong choice.‚Äù SPOKE TO ME ON SO MANY LEVELS

somehow combines all movie + character tropes possible in the typical pinoy cinema fashion but still had me balling my eyes outthis is truly peak pinoy cinema.. beyond the portrayal of a healthy relationship (finally), i truly enjoyed the portrayal of DH workers in HK in full transparency and rawness.. especially with sending remittance back home as Kathryn also to save money (pag-ipunan) for her nursing agency to fly to Canada .. domestic labor is one of the main sources of income for many Filipino women both at home and abroad. even the opening seen, of her running away from authorities because she took an under the table job exposes the difficult reality of DH workers as they strive to make ends meet for their families back home. joy's situation is very lucky compared to other experiences I've heard of DH being abused and exploited by their bosses. other than being a film starring Kathryn Bernado and surprisingly NOT Daniel Padilla, i wonder what power this film could've had on shedding light on the exploitation, rights, and working conditions of DH workers and the "outsourcing" image we have as Filipinosanother line that truly resonated with me was when joy's ama reprimanded joy for abandoning her disabled daughter, annie, on the street.. she unable to pick her up on time.. joy's amma exclaimed, "how could you do this to her, i thought u loved her" this made me think about the complexity of love DH workers face.. in ur job description, you must love other peoples children, u care for them daily, watch them grow up, and essentially fill in this role of a parent to these children all while being miles away from your own family and often times unable to spend quality time with them for years until your contract expires.. to what extent to DH workers feel love towards the children they care for while simultaneously feeling guilt that they cannot be there for their own family or children? one possible answer in resolving these complex feelings of love, guilt, and regret is by reminding yourself your sense of purpose in which most of these DH workers find purpose in their love for their family willing to sacrifice to put food on the table and support the education of their loved ones.. YAYA is fantastic documentary that follows the life of a DH worker who in the director's, justin cheung's, words, "helped build a family at the expense of her own"

this is Cathy Garcia's redemption after a disappointing film, The Hows of Us. I was very impressed on how they showed the struggle and working conditions of Filipino domestic helpers in Hong Kong. it even question the problems of labor export policy and the lack of opportunities and failed social services in the country. the storyline might be predictable yet it is straight to the point, and effective to touch the audiences. Star Cinema might repeatedly used their formula for a romantic-drama/comedy film but they handled it properly. the side story of Kathryn's and Alden's family are justified to be part of the story for us to understand their present decisions. the friends from both sides are only present for comedic purposes but it can be problematic as it serves distraction to the real issue. though, i appreciate the presence of Kathryn's companions who are also domestic helpers. Alden's role fell short from the very beginning and we are left with no assurance of his character development. as well, Alden's pick-up lines are so irritating and I am happy Kathryn was not doing it.above all, this is a breakthrough performance of Kathryn Bernardo as she matured to handle a strong female character and let go from her previous fragile roles. this film proves that Kathryn does not need Daniel to be recognized as a great actress.

It's not an unusual OFW love story but I liked that it's distinctly advocating for standing up for yourself, being individualistic (Joy still choosing herself & Ethan persisted on building a new chance to live a good life), and taking & earning the "2nd chances" in life. It has its problems in regards with the character Ethan (he's pushy and a bit creepy especially in the first part) but regardless, I appreciate that it is realistic to the struggles and situations of being an OFW and the relationship between the couple and the character's family dynamics as well. Thank god that Joy still chose herself in the end (regardless whether or not what happens to the two of them in the said future). Also, I think this is my favorite Kathryn Bernardo's acting so far, she really embodied the complex character of Joy.

I watched this film for my thesis, and I loved it!! It‚Äôs more than just a typical romance film because it also explored the struggles and plights that OFWs experience. Plus, it delivered a beautiful message about dreams and why we shouldn‚Äôt give up on them despite the setbacks we encounter. Ramdam na ramdam ko yung emotions ng story, and ang galing nina Kathryn at Alden dito! They gave such moving performances.However, as much as I love this film, there are some things I didn‚Äôt like:-Too many subplots, and not all of them were done well. As the film focused on Joy and Ethan‚Äôs love story, many subplots got overshadowed and lost their emotional impact. The one with Joy‚Äôs mother towards the end wasn‚Äôt even built up properly.-That fatphobic joke from Joross Gamboa‚Äôs character‚Ä¶ seriously, was that really necessary??-There are so many disabled characters. I appreciate the representation but these disabled characters were just‚Ä¶ there. They didn‚Äôt serve any crucial purpose apart from highlighting the difficulties in Joy and Ethan‚Äôs lives. And why is it that both of Joy and Ethan‚Äôs fathers were disabled? I get that the director may have wanted to portray them as weakened, but frankly, having both of them disabled felt forced. Also, the portrayal of Annie‚Äôs disability is stereotypical.-As other reviewers have said, Alden‚Äôs character (Ethan) is a big red flag. I feel like they could‚Äôve written the conflict without making Ethan a red flag character ‚Äî without making him disregard Joy‚Äôs dream. Also, he was creepy in the beginning. He gave off stalker vibes‚Ä¶-While many of the dialogues were well-written, some felt stiff and forced.-Mary Dale‚Äôs disappearance subplot was unnecessary. It came out of nowhere and lasted only for a while, which undercut the emotions. If they spent more time on it, it would‚Äôve hit harder and would‚Äôve really highlighted Mary Dale‚Äôs plight as an OFW.Nevertheless, despite these criticisms of mine, I really love this film! It made me smile a lot today.

2019 Ranked I need to write an essay about this movie for school, which is why it was necessary for me to rewatch this one. On first viewing, I thought it was overrated. I get the hype because of the director and the cast, but it was cheesy, corny, and irritating to watch. The way I looked at this movie is that I appreciate the drama with regards to their hardships as an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) than the‚Ä¶

Sorry, I DON'T LOVE 'Hello, Love, Goodbye' because of: (1) The story. MA... MAKATOTOHANAN. It's like the romance drama version of the 2016 MMFF Best Picture 'Sunday Beauty Queen'. So much respect for our hardworking OFWs not just in Hongkong but all over the world. You appreciate all the sacrifices they make and feel the longing and suffering they endure just to send money to their loved ones back home. (2) The cast. I've always been a fan of Alden Richards' acting skills and he certainly didn't disappoint. I initially thought the role didn't suit him based on the trailer but he just proved that he's one of the best young actors around. Talagang ramdam mo at maiiyak ka pag ginamit na nang Pambansang Bae ang mga mata niya. The supporting cast were all great from Joross Gamboa, Cacai Bautista and Lovely Abella (these 2 were riotous), MaiMai Entrata, Jeffrey Tam, Jameson Blake to veterans Lito Pimentel, Maricel Laxa-Pangilinan and William Lorenzo to even the local Hongkong actors. But it was Kathryn Bernardo who surprised me the most. She really has grown as an actress from her teleserye days. Since I choose not to see her movies with Daniel Padilla, I never expected her to be so effective and sympathetic as the young woman torn between following her own dreams over love. I thought this was more of her movie than Alden's. (3) The soundtrack. Moira, Moira, Moira. Just hearing her voice in 'Kung 'Di Rin Lang Ikaw' and 'Ikaw At Ako' gave me goosebumps. And these 2 songs were the perfect soundtrack to Ethan and Joy's love story. (4) The setting. Who would've thought that the busy streets of urban Hongkong would look beautiful on the big screen. Kudos to the cinematographer.But if I were to nitpick, it would be that the hugot lines were too many. Joy and Ethan mouthing them all off sometimes felt forced just for the viewers to remember and quote them when they talk about the movie. Nonetheless, ang pelikulang ito ay MA... MASAKIT SA PUSO pero MA... MAGANDANG-MAGANDA. So sorry, I don't love this movie because... I REALLY LOVED it.

It's kind of easy to see why Hello, Love, Goodbye was one of the Philippine's highest grossing films until very recently. It's a romance. The movie it dethroned for highest grossing was also a romance movie, and the one that took its place is also largely a romance (with some time travel thrown in). People love love, but they also love the drama and everything else that comes with it. ‚ÄîAnd boy does Hello, Love, Goodbye have a lot going on. Overwrought emotions, situations with dire circumstances played to dramatic background music, a reluctant at first romance, and so on. Some of this works, I think a romance needs some high stakes and emotionality, some of it falls flat however and doesn't work. I never felt too compelled by the relationship between Joy and Ethan, so the fact that it could've ended at any time was never really upsetting to me. Mostly the movie was just fun, a little silly at times, and the writing could've had another pass but it was an okay watch and more than distracting enough.

As the once highest grossing film in all of Philippine history, I was genuinely surprised that HLG interacted with the overseas foreign worker (OFW) problem that has become an omnipresent yet taboo subject. However, HLG‚Äôs pitfall is ironically the subject it tries to interact with. HLG portrays a tragic, Shakespearian romance as a result of the OFW problem instead of holding up a mirror to its audience and asking why have we let it become the norm in Filo culture that our children must sacrifice their own autonomy to provide for their family? Also (I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm advocating for men) but Ethan is so creepy in this movie, can we please have some non-asshole Filipino male representation on-screen for once pls <3

Immigrants, OFWs, women, and most especially first-born daughters üîõüîùI am honestly raving about this not solely because of the love story, but due to its representation of the aforementioned groups. Despite being privileged with a good life provided by my parents, I still encounter similar struggles, even in minor ways. This makes me ponder how people who have endured worse or comparable experiences truly feel.I believe this film isn't among the highest-grossing due to its love story, but because it resonated deeply with Filipinos. It's challenging to find representations of Filipino struggles in mainstream cinema; most Filipino movies lack such depictions as they primarily focus on love or "kilig." Despite this film containing elements of romance, I'll take what I can get.

One of the best Filipino films I've ever watched. Admittedly at first I thought it would be just like any other usual Filipino romance films with a dash of cringe, so when I finally saw it on Netflix about 2 years ago, it came as a pleasant surprise. Kathryn and Alden's superb performances matched with their palpable chemistry were enough to convince me that this film is worth loving. Plus, I admire the depth the actors gave to their characters and I really felt that they were truly immersed and embodied their characters very well. Also, HLG gave me a peek into the lives of our kababayans, especially of Domestic Helpers in Hongkong. Re-watching it today with my mom made me appreciate the movie even more. It's now my La La Land.Hoping for HLG Part 2!

I like how they used the camera shot type para mapakita ang closeness ng characters. Yung first encounter nina Joy Marie and Ethan eh separate ang shots sa kanila. Then, they have a long talk but since di pa sila close, wide shot ang ginamit. Noong nagkadevelopan na sila, unti-unti na silang may close-up frames.Ok sana yung screenplay kaso may times kasi na nagiging dragging kapag nagdadramahan na at may unnatural blockings like yung nakayakap si Kath sa likod ni Alden. Weird kasi sana me onting PDA man sila prior. However, maraming lessons na napakita dito like balancing self-love and sacrifice pati na rin yung letting go and trusting the person you love.

watched this the first time and i didnt really like it. but now that i watched it again, i understood why this is the highest grossing filipino film. it captured the hardships and realities of what DH Filipinos experience on a subtly deep level. the longing for ‚Äòmore‚Äô but you have to remain in that level just because there is a need to provide. tbh, ethan and joy‚Äôs love story was not the main point of this movie; it was more of a side story that helped resurface joy‚Äôs character of resilience and strength. those characteristics were used by ethan as a stepping stool not to use it against her but to help her. yes, there were some misdirects esp when ethan didnt want joy to leave and didnt understand her situation at first. it was extremely notable how he didnt force her even though he knows he soon can provide and actually just gave her the best possible 3D2N ‚Äòtour‚Äô joy could bring as a memory before she departs. i love that he didnt stray her away from her independence. it couldve went to a whole diff direction where they built a life in HK but, direk cathy made it a point to make sure that the viewers heard and saw what she wanted the movie to focus on. not ur typical love story, so impactful and so realistic esp to filipinos.
